dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH SLOANE (48) stares at us contemptuously. Articu quick-witted and direct:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Lobbying is about foresight. About anticipating your opponent’s moves and devising countermeasures. The winner plots one step ahead of the opposition, and plays her trump card just after they play theirs. She’s actually speaking to her attorney, DANIEL POSNER (4 who stands, frustrated, as that wasn’t the answer he want

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Tell me you’re going to take this seriously when you’re in there. He motions to the DOOR. An atmospheric BUZZ of anticipati emanates from behind it. Elizabeth is seated, unruffled.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s about making sure you surprise them, and they don’t surprise you.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You’re gonna say that? Come on, again: (interrogatory) Could you please describe the nature of your work?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (petulant) Upon the advice of counsel, I must respectfully decline to answer your question, based on my rights under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution. Posner claps sarcastically.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Those words - when you're not taking the oath or confirming details - those words, in that order, are all you're gonna say. (interrogatory) Ms. Sloane, on average, would you say you bribed public officials more or less than once a month?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Upon the advice of counsel - am I allowed to deviate slightly? On the advice of counsel? On the advice of my attorney? I understand if that last one’s too adventurous for you.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You do not-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would be a whole lot easier if I could just shout ‘Fifth’.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: No deviations.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Can I use a silly voice? (silly voice) Upon the advice of counsel... That’s the last straw. Posner deflates, shuts down. A pau The first time we hear the full extent of the RUCKUS outs the waiting room. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: This isn’t a joke. They want you behind bars. You make one statement, correct one nefarious allegation, that’s it. You waive your right to the Fifth and you're compelled to answer everything. You’re being taken to the woodshed in front of the national press, they’re gonna rile you so bad they’d make Gandhi wanna cut their tongues out.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Daniel. When I take the stand, you’1l see nothing but a granite wall.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Good. Elizabeth stands up straight, shoulders back. She makes a minor adjustment to her professional business attire. No but her would’ve noticed the near-imperceptible blemish. Posner glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re on in five. (extends hand) Ms. Sloane. Good luck. She does not shake.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're on retainer, Mr. Posner, to remove luck from the equation. With a subtle shake of the head, Posner turns and trudges The pervasive BUZZ ratchets up the second the door is ope and mutes once more as it closes. Now alone, Elizabeth EXHALES deeply, a valve abruptly unblocked. As if suddenly weak in the knees, she sits bac down. Stares into the middle distance; determination extingiushed from her eyes. She snatches her Fendi handbag and rummages in it. Her ha now tremble, nerves taking hold. She finds what she’s loo for - a small TRINKET BOX. She considers it for a moment, hands still fidgeting. He snap shut. DEEP BREATHS to calm a racing heart. Breathe. Breathe... Breathe. Definitively, she closes her palm on the box as those determined eyes blink back into existence. Elizabeth steps to the desk and rockets the trinket box i the trash can. She grabs her handbag and strides out, hea held high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPORTER gives a live news update.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Sloane is set to take the stand for the first time any moment now; the controversial lobbyist faces charges of bribery and corruption-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: September 14, 2015 The biggest hearing room available to Congress is packed the rafters. JOURNALISTS jostle for a better position. Th public gallery full of important-looking SUITS. TV camera the room. Every square inch taken. The knives are out.

dialogues.speaker: ANALYST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. Traditionally a free-market and anti-tax advocate, Elizabeth Sloane has more recently led a full-frontal assault on the Second Amendment, going up against the Gun Lobby in support of the Heaton-Harris Amendment on gun control; a veritable David vs. Goliath battle for the veteran strategist. Congress is set to allege that Ms. Sloane has made a career out of subverting American democracy...

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Allegations abound of dirty tricks, from giant inflatable rodents to hiring movie extras to... A BARRAGE OF FLASHBULBS greet Elizabeth and Posner as the enter the arena, flanked by FOUR CAPITOL POLICE OFFICERS. The media go into overdrive.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is tight. You’d think they’d choose a more appropriate venue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns out the Redskins had a home game. Elizabeth takes the stand to face SEVEN CONGRESSMEN. Thre on either side of the man leading the assault: Congressman RON M. SPERLING (60s, D-Ohio), Chairman of th House Committee on Ways and Means. A doddery old bumpkin, harmlessly paternal, chummy and relatable. He speaks with solemn authority of someone doing the moral, wholesome bi of the people.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Please raise your right hand. Do you solemnly swear that you will tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, under pains and penalties of perjury?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Please sit. Will the witness please state her full name for the record?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Madeline Elizabeth Sloane.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: And could the witness please confirm these details are accurate, aaahhh... (fumbles through notes) Date of birth, September 18, 1966, current address, 4 Heron Court, Chevy Chase Section 5, Montgomery County, Maryland?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: You won an academic scholarship to study Law at Yale University, where you graduated Summa Cum Laude?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: And you were employed by Cole, Kravitz and Waterman LLP for a ten year period between 2004 and 2014, before moving earlier this year to-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Eleven year period.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There are eleven years between 2004 and 2014.  5. That kills his momentum. He refers back to his notes, sha his head. One of his staffers will pay for that. Elizabet smiles very faintly. A small victory. Posner shakes his h

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: What was the nature of your work at Cole, Kravitz and Waterman LLP?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (deep breath) Upon the advice of counsel, I must respectfully decline to answer your question, based on my rights under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution. A MUTED GROAN from the press as their expectations are me She’s true to her word. A wall of granite.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Did you, November 29th of last year, accept as a client the government of the African Republic of Kenya, for the purpose of campaigning against the levy of additional Federal duties on the importation of palm oil into the United States?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Upon the advice of counsel, I must respectfully decline to answer your question, based on my rights... And so it continues.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, swamped and running on fumes, is followed into toilets by her young protégé, JANE MOLLOY.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Today’s a landmark day, you know why? Because I’m free.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Name one thing you can do today that you couldn’t’ve done yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Quit my job.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You could have done that yesterday, but it would've been stupid.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: But I can quit today and-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It'll still be stupid. You clear your college debt and celebrate by enrolling in post-grad and returning to square one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Academia’s more my scene. Elizabeth enters a stall and latches the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You didn’t follow me into the crapper to gloat about freedom. Talk to me about the Nutella tax. Elizabeth reaches into her handbag for a bottle of water. takes two pills out of the TRINKET BOX we glimpsed earlie and_ gulps them down.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: We're really calling it ‘Nutella tax’?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Palm oil is a key ingredient in Nutella. If the Federal Government taxes it at 300%, it’1ll cost more for us to gorge ourselves on it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Isn't palm oil in pretty much everything?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We could have called it Soap Tax, but the public cares more about Nutella than it does soap. Ross did surveys.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: OK, Estevez, Frame and Albert are in the bag, Hodges-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: See, that should elicit some kind of reaction, but it just doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: -is under pressure. The F&B sector are organized. They represent 7% of the North Carolina economy and accounted for two thirds of job growth over the last twelve months. They're getting loud and he can’t afford to ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Sounds like critical mass to me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do? Elizabeth FLUSHES the toilet (she never went) and exits.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s time we made our move on the sallow little gimp who’s sponsoring this larceny. Tell the Kenyans they're going to host Senator Davis on an all-expenses-paid field trip to one of their plantations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never washed your hands. Elizabeth shrugs it off and washes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He'll take the wife and kids, and whatever luxuries the Kenyan government confer on him will stay between he and them. He’1l come back hailing their conservation efforts and his bill will die a quiet death. They exit the ladies’ room into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a stuffy, conservative stalwart of the D.C. legal indu Walk and talk:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That's legitimate? They can ply him with champagne and truffles?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And diamonds, gold watches, and whatever else. The Congressional gift ban doesn’t apply to sovereign states.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So a Congressman can technically get rich by sponsoring bills that screw foreign governments and wait for them to buy him off?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That’s a little too much work for a class of people who exempt themselves from insider trading laws.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You see? This is why I’m thinking about post-grad.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Jane, we go to school because it prepares us for the real world. You happen to find yourself at the sharp end of the real world at the age of twenty-nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m not so sure I like the ‘real world.’

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So you're going to bury your head in the Socrates?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You know that Socrates never actually wrote anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's beside the point. If you don’t like it, strive to change it. Which is what you’re already doing, that’s why you’re here. See? You’re exactly where you belong. Reasoned into a corner, Jane is silenced. Elizabeth is ho by a young intern (SPENCER).

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Ms. Sloane! They’re ready for you upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Spencer, did you know that Americans care more about Nutella than they care about soap?

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) OK.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Jane) See that? No reaction. They enter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pins stuck in maps, files, boxes, C-SPAN and CNN on the T This is where the ritual morning meeting takes place betw Elizabeth and her team of around TEN LOBBYISTS. Note that these guys are out of kilter with the uptight, paneled ambiance of the firm. Very few of them wear suits these aren’t old boys’ club lobbyists. They’re a young, ambitious team of varying backgrounds who go harder than anyone else and pay lip service to industry mores. They continue to work and confer during the meeting, flit in and out of conversation with their leader. Elizabeth m her rounds. This happens fast, rapid-fire.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Alright, this should be short.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBYIST
dialogues.text: You always say it’s gonna be short.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBYIST
dialogues.text: It’s never short.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It is today. Ross, how many are they expecting at the IMF rally? ROSS is the statistical whizz, early 30s -

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Between five hundred and a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a margin of 100%? (hopeful) Does that technically mean nobody might show up?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Five hundred is really a minimum. The rest depends on things like weather; seems more people hate banks when the sun’s out. Enter PAT CONNORS (40s, Boston-Irish, foul-mouthed and fiercely loyal; the de facto second-in-command) .

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Liz! It’s time we sold Davis on Kenya.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I know-

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: When Hodges falls we've got critic-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Critical mass, I’m aware-—

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: We get him a first class ticket, they give him face and he’1l drop it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Did you just come from the ladies’ room?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: I have no idea what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Ross, how’s the weather forecast for later?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: They put one of these over the whole of Manhattan. Ross draws a weather symbol on the whiteboard - a cloud w rain falling and sunshine behind it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: It’s the internationally recognized meteorological symbol for ‘we don’t have a fucking clue’.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Alright, put Metro Talent on notice, we may need reinforcements. And prep non-disclosures.  FRANKLIN is 10.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: We're really gonna use movie extras?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What’s the quickest way to end an anti-capitalism protest?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Throw a bar of soap in the crowd?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Corrupt their message. Their arguments are immature, but some of these people make valid points. The guy shouting about taxpayers subsidizing bankers’ failure becomes a lot less credible when he’s standing next to a guy styled as a hobo toting a banner that reads “abolish money”.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: “Shit is fucked up and bullshit”. Best banner at Occupy. Tell me that was one of yours.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (shakes head) That was creative way beyond my capabilities. (moving on) Franklin! Shmallow Cakes?! a slightly geeky junior.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Ah - yeah!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So, does sales tax apply to chocolate- covered cakes and chocolate-covered biscuits, or only to one and not the other?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I... Don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You don’t know? (to all) Alright guys, listen up! I’m going to tell you a story.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Please no.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: A priest is giving a young nun a lift home from church one day, and as he’s shifting gear, he rests his hand on the nun’s knee.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: This is offensive and inappropriate.  11.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The young nun looks at the priest and says ‘Father, remember Luke 14:10’. The priest withdraws his hand, embarrassed. Next time they stop at lights, the priest rests his hand a little higher up on her thigh, and again, the nun says ‘Remember Luke 14:10, Father’. The priest apologizes, ‘The flesh is weak’, he says. So he drops her off, and when he gets back home, the priest reaches for his bible and flips to Luke 14:10. Anyone know what it says? Blank stares.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What does it say, Pat?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: (rolls eyes) Friend, come up higher; then shalt thou have glory! Chuckles and sniggers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Know your subject, people! Failure to do so may result in the loss of a golden opportunity. (to Franklin) When I see you this afternoon, you'd better be ready to recite that tax code in Esperanto. (to all, heading to door) That’s it, get to it!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What, we’re done?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: That was short.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I said it’d be short.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You always say it’1l be short.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (exiting; mild disdain) I don’t always have to meet with the prunes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Executive Office is reserved for the most important clients, and feels more like a country club. This morning occupants are: GEORGE DUPONT (a belligerent 82. Head of Government Affai and one of the biggest hitters in the whole firm);  12. R.M. DUTTON (poster-boy lobbyist, 50s, a cold and inhuman tactician with piercing blue eyes); and BOB SANDFORD (60s; powerful and well-connected President the Gun Lobby, and potential golden goose client). They sit in chesterfield leather seats, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: So I’m told I should offer my hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How d’you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: When we meet? I’m told she doesn’t do all the kissy-kissy crap most women do these days.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You two have never met?

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: We've attended the same functions, but never been introduced.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: In a town this small, how does that happen- There is a perfunctory KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: So I should offer my hand?

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: (mildly peeved) I wouldn't worry about it. Elizabeth enters.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ah, here she is. Liz? Bob Sandford, President of the Gun Lobby. She’s quick out of the blocks in offering her hand, a pol and professional evasion of awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'm amazed it’s taken this long.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: I wanted to introduce myself at the Free Enterprise dinner, I’d done my homework - there I got a glimpse into the enigma that is Liz Sloane. You throw the biggest party of the year, and you're first out the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Minor crisis on the hill.  13.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: A lesser commander-in-chief would have left that to a soldier, which is exactly why I’m here. Liz, my organization has reservations about the Heaton-Harris Amendment.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Really... I’m not overly familiar with it, but I heard the Gun Lobby was responsive to proposals to increase the effectiveness of background checks.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: We are, broadly. But the language here is extensive. Longer delays, some Big Brother-type criminal and mental health database, for use on all sales of firearms? Between father and son? Lifelong friends? Our members will view this as an intolerable fetter on the Second Amendment. We want you to be the one to make sure this bill never sees the light of day.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Mr. Sandford, you understand that I deal primarily in taxation and Federal Government interference in free enter-

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: We're well aware. But you and your team take no prisoners and get things done. The reputation you’ve garnered over the past few years, we’ve been practically waiting for an excuse to hire you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (beat) As I say, I’m not familiar with the wording, but if this bill will reduce the likelihood of firearms falling into the wrong hands, it may be in your long-term interests to support it. George and Dutton share a panicked look.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Liz?

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: I don’t understand-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Every time a madman opens fire in public, more support amasses for truly extensive prohibitions on firearms; the more precarious the position of every reasonable gun owner in America. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rigorous background checks should be the Gun Lobby’s best friend. Of course, this would entail telling your five million plus members something they don’t want to hear. Which will guarantee that you'll be a one-term president of the Gun Lobby. But by my reckoning, it’s your best option to secure the future of the Second Amendment. It’s just a question of whether you’d be willing to make the personal sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: Personal sacrifice? (long, uneasy pause Liz... These are extensive.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I see. Well, why don’t I look at the wording and we'll proceed from there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutton just about keeps pace with George, on the warpath.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll look at the wording and proceed from there, who the hell does she think she --

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: This can be spun. At least they know she’s not out to bilk them, that it’s their interests she’s representing. For the purposes of building trust, that may have been the right tactical move.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And do you believe, for one nanosecond, that lobbyist-client bond- building was at the forefront of her mind when she effectively told Bob Sandford to take his business and shove it up his gun barrel?

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: I was just saying... Dutton peels off, and George storms into his office, yell out to his SECRETARY on the way -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I want Sloane in my office now!

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Ah, Mr. Dupont!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George marches in and is taken by surprise-  15.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (re: Secretary) She's good, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You'll look at the wording. Well, I’m sure the President of one of the most powerful representative groups on the hill, will be honored that Her Majesty has agreed to look at the fucking wording!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Did you consider that my lack of enthusiasm might demonstrate to them that I’m protecting their int-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don’t feed me that crap and call it ice cream. What’s going on with you?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Remember when you interviewed me? Eons ago. You asked if I could represent a client whose position I vehemently disagreed with.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Foolishly, I told the truth, I said ‘No.’ Not for money, respect, nor professional integrity. I thought I’d just blown the interview. The next two and a half words out of your mouth were ‘You’re hired’.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What I didn’t tell you is that you’re supposed to have grown out of that infantile, save-the-world idealism by your second year!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I do whatever it takes to win because I only fight for causes I actually believe in-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You’re suddenly a proponent of gun control?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The current system is so porous, it floats. The Heaton-Harris Amendment is necessarily extensive to redress it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought you had to ‘look at the wording’-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I know very well what it says.  16.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When did this happen? I don’t remember you ever caring one way or the other about gun control?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I guess my position solidified somewhere between Columbine and Aurora. Right now, background checks only apply to sales from federally licensed gun dealers. Leaving any two- bit thug or head-case free to procure a thirty-eight special from a gun show, the internet, or his buddy from the Bowl-o-rama. Heaton-Harris puts a full-stop to this stupidity, and about time too.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Christ, Liz, this isn’t any old client waltzing through the door, this is the Gun Lobby. No, something happened - someone you know was a victim of a gun crime.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nonsense. I formed an opinion.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're a champion of the free market. You abhor taxation and frivolous government spending, meddling, patronizing-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I would hardly categorize responsible gun control as frivolous-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Kenyans! For Christ’s sake, you rep Kenyans!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: To stop our all-consuming government from looting one of their few sources of income. There’s a cause I can get behind. And what’s wrong with Kenya? We’re about to close Len Davies with a field trip there.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is that a promise or a threat? I can just picture the good Senator being boiled in a cauldron with all these natives dancing around him. Elizabeth puts her head in her hands, despairing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get some Fortune 500 clients. Your colorful representations are the cause of a lot of industry back-chat this firm’s good name can do without.  Elizabeth's

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Could it do without the thirty grand a month retainer?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You bully people, Liz. You’re a bully, with your unorthodox tactics and endless supply of inflammatory quotes. Senior Partners are banging on my door fearing for our rep, and that’s something I can do without.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're hardly a stranger to “unorthodox tactics”. It'd be quicker to list the Congressmen you haven't strong-armed, threatened or blackmailed. I apply tactical, creative, ethical methods, and that’s how I sleep at night.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Really, Sloane? Those little pills in your purse are the kind that lull you to sleep? eyes narrow. He’s crossing a line.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: My point: we're different animals in the same cage. And I still win, which is why the Gun Lobby just walked through our front door-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And you sent them straight back out of it! You're right! The only reason you and your team of sneaker-wearing ragamuffins are still here is that your arrogant pranks might generate enough buzz to attract clients like the Gun Lobby. Meaning, if you don’t personally dedicate yourself to their cause, the partnership won't really have any use for you. Your billings for this firm’s reputation is a trade they'd be happy to make. Now go away, re-read that amendment, and start telling the world how goddamn extensive it is! ‘S OFFICE - DAY - PAST Elizabeth consults with her DOCTOR. She can’t get out of room fast enough. She reads and responds to emails on her Blackberry, fingertips blistering over the tiny keys like a stenographer on coke.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Any dizziness?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Nausea?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: No disorientation at all?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Doctor, I'm fine, really. Whatever it was you gave me did the trick.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What time d’you go to sleep most nights?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well, it varies-—

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What time did you go to sleep last night? (beat) This morning?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: These are busy times.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: So I see, by your eagerness to get this over with. You don’t need a doctor to tell you you're working yourself into an early grave.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The pills did help me sleep.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Pills aren't the answer. The long hours and levels of stress you’re exposed to would be dangerous for a twenty year-old. (beat ) I’m going to write you a prescription, but it’ll only cover you for the next two weeks. The Doctor scribbles down a prescription and hands it ove

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I want to see you back here ina fortnight, with your phone off, and eight hours under your belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth strides out at pace. Scrunches the prescription deposits it in the nearest trash can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ballroom of a five-star hotel is alive with Washingto most powerful. Phoney affectations, champagne and canapes  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits atop a closed commode with her head in her hands, savoring invisibility and relative quiet. A lifeti ‘being on’ has taken its toll; like she herself is buildi towards critical mass. She reaches into her handbag and flips open her trinket b She looks tired, burnt out. She considers the four pills inside long and hard, but denies herself. She flips it sh flushes (she never went), and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth strides from the hotel on a crisp winter’s nigh and is caught up by a PERSISTENT MAN in his 40s.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: Early night?! She doesn’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If you’re here for a quote, you’re wasting both of our time. Neither does he.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: I’ve just watched you extricate yourself from three conversations to use the ladies’ room in the space of thirty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You busted me. I’m incontinent. Go ahead, write it up.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: I hope I’m wrong, but one could be forgiven for thinking you're sick of this town. She looks at him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I haven’t seen you before. You work for the Post? How’d you get in?

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: I'd like five minutes of your time.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The walk to my car is three, get to the point.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: Word on the hill is that the Gun Lobby approached you to bury Heaton- Harris. And you refused.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I don’t comment on ‘the word on the hill’.  20.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: I know there’s no way you’d do that... Unless you support gun control. You know why you’re good, Liz? Same reason Ayrton Senna was the greatest auto racer of his time. The same reason terrorists are scary.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m not sure a three-way comparison between myself, a dead race car driver, and Al-Qaeda is a good use of your remaining hundred-and-thirty- five seconds.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: A terrorist will strap himself to a bomb for his cause. Senna believed God was protecting him from harm, so he threw himself around corners, fully committed. You won’t find a mercenary on Earth willing to do either. You’re good because you believe in your clients’ causes; conviction-lobbying. And belief motivates people in ways money just can’t.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I said ‘get to the point’-

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: The Sloane Ranger, sticking up for corporate America against the thieves on the hill, clawing at hard-earned profit to fund frivolities like healthcare. Her ears prick up. Her retort is instant and impassioned.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Or because private property is the foundation of civilized society, I object to any entity being forcibly expropriated of the product of their labor. And you wanna talk about frivolities, those thieves on the hill just spent nearly a million dollars of someone’s hard labor funding research into methane emissions made by dairy cows. I accept a minimum rate of taxation for necessities, but a meddling, all- consuming government constricts freedom, throttles innovation, and subverts the free market. All of which destroy standards of living.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: (shrugs, nonplussed) Personally, I’m all for more gun control. Will you admit the present system is unfit for purpose?  21.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I remain committed to the Second Amendment.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: Dildos are illegal in Texas, but Joe Public can walk into a sports store and emerge five minutes later with a shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That would explain the low rate of dildo-related murders in Texas. The Man LAUGHS heartily.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that funny.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: No, but you just proved my point. The mere mention of taxation elicits a libertarian polemic. All I get from gun control is a sarcastic deflection. You do support Heaton- Harris, and you abhor the tactics your leadership would employ in discrediting it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Alright. You have unusual acuity for a member of the D.C. press. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: Your quote.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Fine: a conviction-lobbyist never cheats; she exposes cheaters. He scribbles on a notepad.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: That's a keeper. One more thing - off the record - d’you know anything about the Gun Lobby’s opponents?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What, Brady? I know they’re going to lose because their total budget comes to less than what the Gun Lobby pay to get their shoes shined-

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: What about their lobbyists, Peterson Wyatt? They’re a boutique law firm with a bi-partisan Government Affairs division-  22.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: ‘Boutique’ is a euphemism for ‘little fish’ and ‘bi-partisan’ denotes a bunch of hippies in suits, some of whom are mercenary enough to swing right when times get hard.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: D’you know anything about their President? Guy named Schmidt?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Never heard of him. But if the firm is built in his image, he’s probably a simpering wuss with a Ph.D in style- over-substance.

dialogues.speaker: PERSISTENT MAN
dialogues.text: Got it. (beat) I never introduced myself, by the way. Rodolfo Schmidt, President of Peterson Wyatt. Elizabeth stops. She is, for once, speechless. RODOLFO SCHMIDT (CONT’D) What’s the matter? Am I not simpering hard enough?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (thinking out loud) Your firm’s only twelve years old, you'd think your name would either be Peterson or - (snaps out) What’s this about?

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You're pro-Heaton-Harris and it’s an open secret you're at war with your firm’s leadership. (beat) The Brady Campaign want you to lead the fight to pass the bill. Peterson Wyatt will employ you as a consultant, you’ll run defense out of our office, and when it’s over you’re free to choose from any of the D.C. behemoths in line for your signature. This is their quote. He writes down a number we don’t see and tears off the pi of paper he scribbled on earlier. She regards it with a s now wise to his strategy.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (re: offer) I don’t know if I should be flattered or insulted, Mr. Schmidt, but you clearly have the wrong opinion of me. Especially considering the battle you've got ahead of you.  23.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I think my opinion of you is spot-on. His earnestness halts any immediate retort from her. She studies him. RODOLFO SCHMIDT (CONT’D) Don’t even think about telling me you don’t wanna take a swing at this. Maybe you’re the only one in this town who can pull it off. Anyway, it’s on the table. I’ve overspent my three minutes. Rodolfo walks off, but turns back - RODOLFO SCHMIDT (CONT’D) Where’s your car? Long pause. Elizabeth motions back down the street, from they came.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Three blocks that way. INT. ELIZABETH’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - NIGHT - PAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s late. All is quiet, dark. Elizabeth downs a tall gla milk. She puts the bottle back in the fridge, but stops b she closes the door. Considers the milk. EXT. ELIZABETH’S HOUSE - NIGHT - MOMENTS LATER - PAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth carefully sets down a saucer full of milk on he front doorstep. Takes a wistful look around the posh, pea neighborhood. The pervasive stillness a touch unsettling. INT. ELIZABETH’S HOUSE - NIGHT - LATER - PAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits in an armchair and leans forward. Her eyes around the room, she fidgets, unable to turn her brain of As if deciding to stop thinking once and for all, she lea back, closes her eyes and ceases all movement. Deep breat an attempt to induce sleep. It’s no use. She snaps out of it quickly, turns on a lamp snatches a book next to her - John Grisham's The Litigato Starts reading from her bookmark (she’s not far in), but discards it in no time. She’s wired. An idea has taken ho She glimpses around her place. It’s not a home; more a warehouse for files, boxes, and neatly-organized work-rel clutter. No family portraits. No photographs of a husband children. On hearing a faint MEOW, Elizabeth glances out the front window. A stray cat and two kittens lick the milk she set Elizabeth lets out a SIGH, as if this provides her some s measure of comfort. She catches her reflection in the win Ruffled and sleepless. She removes something from her pocket - the torn-off SHEE A NOTEPAD given to her by Rodolfo Schmidt. She considers then grabs her cell and makes a call.  24.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Jane, hi -- I know what time it is, just listen. I had a thought... So, if Socrates never wrote anything, how is it that anyone has ever heard of him? (beat) Yes, I’m fine. Look, we need to meet... No, as in, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning meeting in full swing. Elizabeth quizzes her charge, Jane:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They're staying at the Lantana?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That’s the one on the beach?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: OK, make the bookings. Cover it out of the pooled account. New fish Franklin is within earshot.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Is that OK? Technically, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It’s just - the Kenyan government are paying for this, right? That’s how we get around the gift ban. The pooled account’s, well... Pooled. There’s money in there from the F&B Association, Wal-Mart, anyone with an interest in selling anything with palm oil in it. (off their surprise) I majored in Finance, I go over accounts when I want to look busy-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So you’ll know the Kenyans’ contribution to that account is big enough to cover Senator Davis’ expenses ten times over and have change for a small Caribbean island. Do I look unduly concerned?

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Connors steams in, wolfing down a chocolate muffin.  25.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: George told me what happened with the Gun Lobby, are you retarded?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No, but coming from someone who just walked in an hour late, looking like he pulled his face out of a cow pie, that’s mildly amusing.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: That wasn’t funny and I don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Pray tell, why are you eating a chocolate cake for breakfast? Have you no shame?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: It’s a muffin, you never ate a muffin for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: A muffin, let me see... Eggs, flour, sugar, cocoa powder, milk, chocolate. Sounds exactly like a cake, but of course no civilized person could ever eat chocolate cake for breakfast. So some bright spark in marketing divvied up yesterday's leftovers, re- branded them as ‘muffins’ and started hawking them as breakfast food.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: You've lost your mind-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Franklin, are you getting this? ‘Cause I’m really talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Shmallow Cakes aren’t really cakes. They're marshmallow paste sandwiched between two biscuits covered in chocolate. America’s fourth favorite snack is 80% graham cracker. And while our ever-rational tax code deems cakes luxury items and hits them harder, biscuits are obviously necessities, and exempt. Are you getting this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Have Shmallow Cakes re-designated as biscuits, argue the ‘cake’ in the name is merely marketing puff. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muted GASPS. 26.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll need evidence in court, so have a team of scientists chemically analyze their composition and opine they are in fact 80% biscuit and zero percent cake. That’s how you win.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You knew that all along?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You’d have got there eventually.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Then why are you telling me this?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: In case you’re not coming with me.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: What the hell’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Everybody, listen up! As you may have heard, I took a meeting with the Gun Lobby a week ago, and advised them to support the Heaton-Harris Amendment. (deep breath) Effective immediately, I’ve decided to leave Cole, Kravitz and Waterman and take up station as a consultant for the Brady Campaign at Peterson Wyatt. Raised eyebrows. Nobody saw this coming. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) In negotiating terms, I secured places on my team for everyone in this room with no change to your current rates of compensation. Now who's with me on this? Pat?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: I just walked in an hour late ‘cause I’ve been assuring the Gun Lobby that we're the right firm to lead the fight against Heaton-Harris. We just got the green fucking light.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are you saying I should put you down as a maybe?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: You can’t possibly win this.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Who's with me? Silence. Nobody dares make the first move... Until:

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I'm with you. Ross, the statistician, goes and stands behind Elizabeth.  27.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Ross, come on, I need you.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: She needs me more. Franklin follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Guns frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: The fuck is this? Jerry Maguire?!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You've seen Jerry Maguire? That’s not gay at all.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: It’s because I’m not gay that I’ve seen Jerry Maguire, you fag prick. MURMURS. Lauren and Alex defect to Elizabeth’s side.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So, Sloane et. al. versus Connors, and who else? Ramirez. How many Tec- 9s do you own again?

dialogues.speaker: LOBBYIST
dialogues.text: Enough to defend my property. Plus two more to piss off lefties.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Travis, Wickham and Moore, the God- squad, the Bible says thou shalt not kill, yet you openly endorse instruments of death.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBYST
dialogues.text: For some silly reason I thought you hated government interference in people’s lives.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Silly indeed. I hate unnecessary interference; those bits of interference which prohibit private citizens from purchasing anti-tank ordnance, or weapons-grade plutonium, I can live with. She turns to Jane, who sits motionless, staring into spac

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Jane... (no response) Jane?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t know where I stand on this.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I do, you stand with me.  28.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Seriously kid, go. I couldn’t care less.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Actually... The Gun Lobby will need someone to tally their vote count in Ross’ absence... I'll stay.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Jane!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You were right before. I’m at one of the best firms in the city. People come and go. I won’t let that affect my career here. I’1ll miss you, but the 3am wake-up calls? Not so much.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: No shit, I take it back. Welcome aboard.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (wounded) Fine. And for what it’s worth, you’ve some way to go until your vote counts are anywhere near as accurate as Ross’. (snaps to Ross, who beams) Don’t let it go to your head. (his smile dies; to all) I’m off to say my goodbyes to the bean-counters. Ordinarily, I'd say good luck, but-

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: You're going down harder than Bin Laden.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (exiting) Your ass is mine, punk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the hearing, Elizabeth is stone-faced, but fidget slightly. The wall of granite slowly being chipped away. We now recognize some of the faces in the public gallery: George Dupont, Connors, Rodolfo Schmidt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman Sperling is doddery and sanctimonious as usua

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: We'll come back to the African Republic of Kenya later, but... (sickly pious) You see, what troubles me is the amount of influence you had... We've seen communications from senior figures in Washington; it’s like you had this aura, nobody dared get in your way. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Upstanding, democratically elected officials feared you, a lobbyist, could destroy their careers with a snap of your fingers, I... He stops, looks down, shakes his head in disbelief. CONGRESSMAN SPERLING (CONT’D) Folks whose careers took decades of hard work, they... Is this reputation something you actively cultivated, Ms. Sloane?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Upon the advice of counsel, I must respectfully decline to answer your question, based on my rights under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: You see, it’s bad enough one person having that much influence, but if they're out of control - if she has a problem, an addiction... Which precludes her from exerting her influence even-handedly... It'd be like the ship of American politics being steered by a drunk. Do you, or have you ever had, any problems with substance abuse, Ms. Sloane? Elizabeth’s eyes narrow. Unsure what he’s getting at.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (sharply) Upon the advice of counsel, I must respectfully decline to answer your question, based on my rights under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution. The media pick up on her tone and WAKE from their slumber

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: I understand you have difficulty sleeping? We subpoenaed medical records, you’re a long-time sufferer of chronic insomnia. You regularly work over sixteen hours a day. So you suffer from a lot of fatigue, but can’t get off to sleep, is that accurate? Elizabeth is indignant, her privacy violated. Thrown by t line of questioning, she stumbles over her wording:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Upon the advice of counsel, I respectfully - I must respectfully decline to answer your question, based on my rights under the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution. To the Constitution. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under breath) Whatever. The media STIR more, sensing the next chapter of the scan

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: You were prescribed multiple courses of benzodiazepines, but according to the deposition of one of our witnesses, you've been procuring, off- prescription, and against the advice of your medical practitioner, a course of psycho-stimulants, with the aim of keeping you awake and alert for longer. Is this correct? MURMURS in the public gallery and among the media. Elizab aims a venomous stare at George Dupont, knowing him to be only one with that information. He sits up straight and p out his chest, revelling in vengeance for her betrayal. Her next death-stare falls on Posner. He can only endure helpless. He has no grounds to object. Flashbulbs POP in her face. CONGRESSMAN SPERLING (CONT’D) Ms. Sloane?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (reeling it off, fast) Upon the advice of counsel, I must respectfully decline to answer your question, based on my rights under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: OK... Returning to this business in the African Republic of Kenya-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (involuntary blurt) I_am not a drug addict and this line of questioning has no relevance to this case. MEDIA FRENZY. A barrage of FLASHES. Her silence broken. P bows his head. She’s blown it. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) (fast and angry) My medication doesn’t affect my judgment any more than a double espresso, and speaking of intoxication, I can recite from memory a list of ‘upstanding, democratically elected’ Congressmen who have voted on legislation while severely inebriated. And just so you know, I think, by now, everyone in this room is fully aware, and in no danger of forgetting, that Kenya is a republic which happens to be situated on the continent of Africa.  31. A long pause. All eyes, all cameras, on Elizabeth. She deflates a little, the consequences of that outburst now weighing on her mind. Congressman Sperling smiles a cunning, near-imperceptible smile. A huge victory. There’s a lot more to this guy tha fuddy-duddy demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Ms. Sloane. Welcome to the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Posner is furious. Elizabeth remains phlegmatic throughou

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Five years, was it really worth it? Five years minimum-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What’s five years-

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: All for some puerile quip about Kenya being in Africa, can’t you see that whole construct was designed to -- and it worked!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You want to tell me what five years is?

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You fell for it! The smartest operative on the hill just got played by Grampa Simpson!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Is it how long this recess will feel like?

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: It’s the going rate for perjury before Congress. Which, now that you've thrown the Fifth out the window, anyone who wants you in the ground - and that’s a_ lot of people - they’re hard at work, dedicating the sum total of their creative and intellectual efforts to catch you in a lie.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What if I stay silent?

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s a good idea! Shit, why didn’t your lawyer think of that?!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If I simply refuse to answer-  32.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: They’11l throw you in jail for contempt of Congress. You’ve just blown this thing wide open. He paces, agitated. Elizabeth looks at him, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Easy, Daniel. You’re starting to look like you care.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: I don’t care about you any further than I can throw you. I work for the one ethical lobbying practice on the hill, and I wind up defending the poster-child for the most morally bankrupt profession since faith healing. Rest up, Sloane. You're gonna need it. Posner snatches his briefcase and storms out. Elizabeth remains seated, alone in the large, empty room. ECU: she clamps her palms together, her trembling hands struggling to settle.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Elizabeth strides into the lobby, talking on her Blackber She makes a beeline for the elevators without stopping to admire the decor. She knows her way around this place.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: We need to get to it right away, office space or not. (beat) I think you’1l find I started working for you the night we met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth opens the door, but stops dead in her Ann Taylo Her glare cuts into -- FORDE, sprawled out on the bed. It’s immediately obvious a different animal to the D.C. crowd we’ve met thus far. rugged good-looks, easy smile and natural confidence. Bou glass resting on his toned chest, above hard-earned abs. Jeans’ top button unhooked. His Southern accent drawls li dulcet tune.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Evenin’, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What happened to the usual guy? Mark. If that’s his real name.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Mark’s moved on. You can call me Forde.  33.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Is that your real name?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Is to you. What do I call you, gorgeous? Elizabeth scoffs at the flattery, enters the room. She pe around, suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Alright, Nothin’. You a politico, or one’a these corporate-types? And what brings a fine lady like you to room

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not the conversation. She motions to a tumbler of bourbon on the bedside table. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) How much have you had to drink?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: With a free minibar, I’d say not nearly enough. He salutes her and drains his glass. Elizabeth inhales.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You know, you’re not allowed to smoke in here.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to buy company in here, yet here you are-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Smoke is detectable. It could draw attention. It’s unprofessional.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: OK. Corporate-type. Lawyer maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If we’re to go forward, I require certain standards of-

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Agency rules, Ms. Nothin’. Payment in cash, we’re not seen in public, unless that’s what ya want, and I’m the only one to ever lay eyes on you or know this 1i’l party ever happened. Tonight, that’s with half a minibar down my gullet. (beat) ‘Course, I understand if you were... Lookin’ for somethin’ else. A rare moment of vulnerability. Elizabeth looks him over.  34.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You'll do just fine. Let’s get to the point. All business, Elizabeth unbuckles the belt on her pantsui fastidiously lays it over the back of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very different meeting room in a modern, open plan, and somewhat pretentiously “progressive” neo-industrial offic Art installations made from used milk bottles, etc. The four defectors from Elizabeth’s team sit awkwardly wi FOUR of their new COLLEAGUES (30s, three female, all Democrats). They’ve said their hellos, sat down (in their factions), and are now struggling for small talk.

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON WYATT LOBBYIST, (BRIAN)
dialogues.text: So... What d’you guys think of the new office?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It’ll take some getting used to.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I kinda like it. Reminds me of Willy Wonka’s chocolate factory.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's funny, you remind me of an Oompa Loompa.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: The vending machine downstairs is weird. It wouldn’t dispense my beverage unless I told it my gender and age range.

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON WYATT LOBBYIST, (ESME)
dialogues.text: The vending machine company sells our personal details to Big Advertising. I already lodged a complaint with upper management.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It’s OK, I just lied.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What, you told it you’re an adult male?

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON WYATT LOBBYIST, (CLARA)
dialogues.text: Why are you so horrible to him?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It’s polite to reciprocate.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (checking phone) Davis dropped the Nutella Tax.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: When did this happen?  35.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I just got it-

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON WYATT LOBBYIST, (CYNTHIA)
dialogues.text: The tax on palm oil? You’re the ones who killed it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Dead with the dodo.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Along with how many other unique species in the Kenyan rainforest?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (to Ross) Not your greatest analogy there.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (to Cynthia) I guess that’s for them to decide, after all, it is, you know, their country.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: D’you know how much pollution their slashing and burning pumps into the atmosphere?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Less than 0.2% of global greenhouse gas emissions. Would you like to know by how many orders of magnitude the American industrial revolution eclipsed them, so we could grow fat off all that Nutella?

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: I’d love to. But I know you can’t tell me, ‘cause it’s not even close to quantifiable.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh God, it’s started already.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Are the rumors true?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Elaborate.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Sloane-zilla. Is she the personification of an ice cube?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Melts at room temperature and gave Canadians a national pastime?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Frigid and heartless.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: She pees standing up. I don’t even do that.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Do you think before you speak?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Why don’t we just focus on the future? OK?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Let's. Silence makes an instant return. People check their phone Backs straighten as Elizabeth and Rodolfo enter.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I was thinking we start by going round the room and introducing our-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Let’s spare ourselves the tedium and get to it. If you want to break the ice, do it with insight. Whatever our differences, political or otherwise, we're all here to ensure safe passage of the Heaton-Harris Amendment into Federal law. How do we do it? A brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Realistically, we don’t. We fight them as hard as we can, build a strong base of support, so we have a better chance when they table next year’s Heaton-Harris, or the one after that.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: While I appreciate your pragmatism, I didn’t just move across town with the aim of losing as slowly as possible. Name and seniority?

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Esme Manucharian, nine years.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Manucharian. I’ve heard that name.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Esme’s our authority on gun control. When it comes to facts and figures, she has no equal. Ross’ note scribbling practically does a record scratch. needles him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You led the fight to preserve the concealed carry ban in Illinois.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Ultimately unsuccessfully, but yes.  37.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Esme. Why are we going to lose?

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: For every dollar we can donate in campaign contributions, you know how much the Gun Lobby can donate?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS ESME
dialogues.text: Thirty-eight. Thirty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (grins at rivalry) So Congressmen bow to money, but why? It’s not going into their own accounts, that'd be bribery.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Like what the Kenyans just did to Senator Davis?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That was legal, sovereign-backed bribery, but yes. (beat ) Every rational entity protects their interests. The priority of a Congressman isn’t representing the people, it’s keeping his ass in office. Campaign contributions are a means to that end, which is why Congressmen sell their votes to get them.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: That is so cynical.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There is no cynicism. Only a word used by Polly-Annas to denote an absence of the naivety they so keenly exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) You settle in fast.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: So Congressmen bow to money so they can get re-elected, and we’re shit out of money.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: So we do it the old-fashioned way, by direct appeal to voters. Elizabeth regards Clara with a fleeting glance. But still than any one person (bar Esme) has received from her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Thank you. The average lobbying fight is won rather plainly: greasing the right Congressmen at the right moments. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But to win here, against these odds, will require us rounding those bases many times over - and so will our strategy... (CLAPS hands) Everybody up! We’re going mobile.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: We are?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is about appealing to Jane and Joe Public. It may be a political battle, but it needs to be fought on the street. We approach this, not as Washington insiders, but as normal Americans.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You're going to try to be normal?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) This I have to see.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You can work in this sanitized sardine can if you want. I'll be at America’s favorite pastime with 40,000 of our marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Orioles game is well underway as sunset crayolas the Baltimore skyline. The ten members of the team look out o 40,000 spectators from a private skybox.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Campaign contributions don’t create binding obligations, they’re debts of honor. If, on polling day, a Congressmen thinks a vote against will be political suicide, he'll betray the Gun Lobby to save his ass even if they funded surgery to whiten his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: A skybox? At a hundred times the price of an average ticket? This is your attempt at being normal?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We can talk shop in relative privacy. I’m compromising.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: However much we spend to get the public on our side, the Gun Lobby can afford to drown us out.  39.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And here's the beauty of it; the reason we have any chance at all: we don’t need to spend to get the public on our side. They already are. There are 40,000 people in this stadium. Polls show that 32,000 of them favor gun control, just not vehemently enough to change their vote over it, and further objurgate the painfully- obscure language of the Second Amendment.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: So we spend to make gun control the deal-breaker.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Exactly. America has endured 31 school shootings since Columbine, more than double the amount in the rest of the world put together. Yes, Franklin. We make guns a deal- breaker. We start a movement, build a consensus, do everything we can to make it snowball. That's how we win. Down on the field, players trudge off for a time-out. Sixpence None the Richer’s Kiss Me BOOMS around the stadi

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: This is moot, but just so you know, baseball isn’t America’s favorite pastime anymore. Statistically, I mean. The NFL has polled-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I already knew that, and it’s not moot. The NFL season kicks off little over a month before Heaton-Harris goes to vote. Average attendance of 67,000, tens of millions watching on TV. The romantic music has the effect of making Elizabeth mor aggressive. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) This is where Jane and Joe reside. I want pro-Heaton-Harris ads on the big screen, I want TV spots; the public don't pay heed to politicians, they listen to their heroes. We get hold of sports agents and brow-beat them into having their charges pledge support for increased gun control- She stops, as some of her team become distracted.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (to Clara) Ah, guys... Horror washes over Clara’s face, as she looks to --  40. THE JUMBOTRON. KISS CAM has homed in on her, standing bes Alex. He smirks, relatively unruffled. Clara pleads with big screen as though it can understand her.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: No, no, we're not - we just met! The crowd grow restless as Alex and Clara stand, not kiss Playful BOOS begin to ring out. This is awkward.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Ah, what the hell... Alex grabs Clara and pulls her close in front of him, til his head to the right. From the camera view on the giant screen, they appear to be kissing. NEW ANGLE - they are, in fact, not quite touching. Alex c his eyes and expertly caresses her cheek with his fingert

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whisper) Tilt your head ever so slightly to the right. She does. The crowd GOES NUCLEAR. Alex pulls back, smiles Kiss Cam moves on to the next unsuspecting couple.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Very well saved. Clara, despite her best efforts, looks genuinely impresse

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (cocky bastard) You wanna try the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are you done? Can we get back to it now?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: So much for ‘relative privacy’.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Should've stayed in the office. INT. GUN LOBBY - BOB SANDFORD’S OFFICE - DAY - PAST GUNS. Pictures of guns. Model guns. A golden gun. He’s a pound bull and you wouldn’t mess with him anyway, but Bob Sandford's office isn’t designed to make you feel welcome He leans back in his executive chair, King of his empire. the hardened Connors is unusually subdued.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: We're a powerful institution, Pat. There’s over five million of us. And we're armed. Now I’m not saying we set out to intimidate, but when the Gun Lobby wants to meet you, you damn well meet.  41.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Who are we talking about here?

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: Wickman, Democrat, Wisconsin. Always seems to be unavailable to take our call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU ON A FLAT-SCREEN TV: News coverage of a press confere A grief-stricken father, JOEL PATTERSON, sniffles and fig tears as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL PATTERNSON
dialogues.text: We’ve seen this a million times before. This speech. This situation. It seems so far away. You never think this is going to be you giving it. My girls died... He takes a long pause, trying to compose himself. Connors, R.M. Dutton, and Jane watch the TV. There is gen sympathy in the eyes of the latter.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: (rolls eyes; to himself) Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL PATTERNSON
dialogues.text: We could have stopped this... On the TV, Joel breaks down in tears. It’s rather heartbreaking. However, R.M. Dutton is nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: We get the idea. Jane clicks off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Joel Patterson, high school history teacher. There was a renewed wave of anti-gun sentiment in Wisconsin after his wife and two children were shot dead in a mall.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: That was months ago-

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It hasn't died down. Big media still runs coverage on him. Mothers against guns marches, there was an online pledge to vote against anyone who opposes gun control-

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: This is her. Public outrage after a gun attack lasts around a week per casualty, this whole Pattinson story should be in the ground by now.  42.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Patterson.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Their name. The Patterson family.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shit if they were the Partridge Family. She’s revived this.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Actually, she’s cultivated it. Public support for gun control’s up 8% in the last two weeks alone. Wickman’s avoiding the Gun Lobby ‘cause if he gives them what they want, there’s a very real chance he won’t make it through fall.

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: Why didn’t we close him earlier?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: It’s Wisconsin, it’s not exactly... Where is she now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team hard at work, making calls, crunching numbers. An entire wall is dedicated to bio mugshots of Congressme with red slashes over some and green ticks over others. S have no markings. This is their vote count. Ross stands and admires it with Cynthia, Franklin and Esm

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: 217's the magic number. 217 gets us a majority-

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I thought 218 is a majority-

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: (cutting in) In a House of 435, it is, but three vacant seats gives us 432, meaning 217-215 is the smallest possible winning majority.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: As. I. Was. Saying... (eyeing Esme) By my reckoning, the Gun Lobby has 191 votes pretty much locked - (motions to wall) That’s this side. I’d say we have 183 locked over on this side. That leaves 58 who are in play: these fine gentlemen in the middle. Heaton- Harris provisionally makes it to the floor in 179 days. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The good news is, if we lock down 34 of these money-sucking leeches, we’re over the line.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: The bad news being that the Gun Lobby are rich beyond our wildest dreams?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: There is that-

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Or that it’s not a whole lot of time to steal 34 votes from the most powerful lobby in D.C.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That too-

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: What Ross is fumbling around is, they only need 26.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (finally) Yes. Elizabeth marches through the office, on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: No, we need the media there, that’s the whole point. It has to be recorded on celluloid, ready to be trotted out should he ever think about backing down - hold on - (calling out) Ross?! You get it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Yeah! Twelve billion a year, $32 per gun in circulation!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: OK, good. I’m sending you a photo of Clara Thomson, she’ll be seated front- left, wearing - (calls out) Clara, what are you wearing?!

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: One-shoulder black crepe dress!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: A one-shoulder black crepe dress. If you're really lucky, she’ll find you at the reception. Thank you, Carlos. She hangs up. To Alex, passing by - ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Alex, tell me it’s feasible that a doctor wouldn’t have time for all this social media lark?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: If you're pulling fifteen-hour shifts, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Linked In. If he’s a doctor he’d probably be on Linked In.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Could you not have just stopped when I said ‘great’? She collapses into a chair and snatches up a medical text titled PULMONARY PATHOPHYSIOLOGY. Rodolfo Schmidt passes.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Light reading?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: D’you even know what Pulmonology is?

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: It’s the study of... Pulmon.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Did you know your lungs are asymmetrical? Your right lung has three lobes, but your left is smaller, it has two. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Your heart needs the real estate?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Bravo.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Though I guess that’s not a problem for you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Ouch, that hurt. Come, what do they got? Let’s have it.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: (consults notes) It’s the first step toward a national register of firearms.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nobody’s even come close to proposing that, and if anyone did, it’d have its own day in Congress. Linking that to Heaton-Harris is scare mongering.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: The new rules will increase wait times by as long as two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Two whole weeks, how will they survive? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome to America, where you'll wait six months for a routine operation, but hey, you can buy an AR-15 in five minutes flat.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Anderson Cooper's earliest booking is late-May. You going to be that flippant on CNN?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes. Pussyfooting isn’t memorable. Sound bites are, and the appropriate one here goes like this: anyone that desperate to get their hands on a gun shouldn’t be allowed anywhere near one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ballroom is decked out for a big fundraiser. Banners the AMA (American Medical Association) adorn the podium a CONGRESSMAN WALLACE gives a speech. Clara, wearing a black, one-shoulder crepe dress, weaves way through tables while on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You think he'll go for it? OUTSIDE THE BALLROOM, Elizabeth paces, on her cell:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: He knows the media is here and won’t risk being heckled at his own fundraiser. You'll back him into a corner and he’1ll have no choice. LATER - Congressman Wallace stands on the platform and th roving MC selects people to ask questions.

dialogues.speaker: MC
dialogues.text: Just a couple more questions for the Congressman and we’ll wrap up. Clara’s hand shoots up. The MC sees her, but his glance m further afield.

dialogues.speaker: MC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, the lady in white. Clara puts her cell phone to her ear. The unseen lady in has a bland, scripted Q and A with the Congressman.
