dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: He was supposed to go to me third, what’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Following orders. Three tables behind you, four to your left. Clara looks back. Connors, R.M. Dutton, Jane, and Ramirez share a table. Connors catches her gaze. She looks away.  46.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: They've been following us since Wisconsin. They’d have had everyone on that list vetted. You’re blown.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You made me delete my Facebook account. I had my bio removed from our website-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: To make it look like we tried.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: What d’you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MC
dialogues.text: And the final question goes to... Clara’s hand shoots up again, but the MC reads from a car

dialogues.speaker: MC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dr. Raj Amarasekara - I hope I’m pronouncing that right - of the Pulmonary Associates of America. RAJ AMARASEKARA stands to pose his question.

dialogues.speaker: RAJ AMARASEKARA
dialogues.text: Mr. Congressman. Where I work, on any given night, it’s a safe bet we'll see three or four gunshot victims. Some are kids, teenagers. I think we can all agree this is a problem, so I'd like you to tell us how you intend to vote on the Heaton-Harris Amendment when it’s put before Congress. Thank you. The question receives LOUD APPLAUSE from the audience. Yo tell the press in the room because they just scrambled fo their cameras and phones, and proceed to record the momen ON ELIZABETH, inconspicuous towards the back, on the phon

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I mean Raj Amarasekara is a working actor whose real name is Matthew Kantaria. They thought he was about to ask a benign question about a clean air initiative. Connors is steaming mad. R.M. Dutton, death cooled down. The Congressman does his best to conceal his unease. Paus

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You _decoyed me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Raj Amarasekara has personally plagiarized seven research papers, all available online. He even has a Linked In account.  47.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN WALLACE
dialogues.text: Well... As you said, and have experienced, gun violence is a real problem... And while our sympathies must always be first and foremost with the families of the victims, it must also be noted the enormous strain gun violence puts on our healthcare system. (uneasy pause; in a bind) That’s why, when put to vote... I will whole-heartedly support the Heaton-Harris Amendment. LOUD APPLAUSE. Congressman Wallace puts on his best plast smile and laps it up, but behind it lurks one angry man. Elizabeth surveys a sea of camera phones held up by atten which just captured the moment.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to herself) And that’s a wrap. She turns on a sixpence to exit, but stops - she catches Jane's gaze from across the room. Her old protégé, now an adversary. Neither dwells on it - Elizabeth strides out; sips her drink casually. BACK IN THE OFFICE, CLOSE-UP ON THE VOTE COUNT: Congressm Wallace's face gets a BIG GREEN TICK stuck over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth rolls off Forde in bed, post-coital. They stare the ceiling. It takes a moment for her breathing to norma but when it does:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I could use this room tonight. I have work to do. She gets out of bed and dresses. Forde rolls onto his sid

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Big case?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Forde, human interaction is an exchange. My money for your...

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Dick?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Let’s call it “skill set” - is the only exchange I’m willing to make.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Now ya sound like a banker. (beat ) I was hopin’ we could getta know each other a li’l. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FORDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you ever need an excuse to get outta the office, or wherever it is you work, I’d be happy to meet downtown for a cup of Joe. Just as two normal people. Not, you know...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (smiles) While I admire your persistence, that’s never going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Suit y’erself. (rolls out of bed) I got prep to do anyways.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Prep for what?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: (dressing) ‘Nother client, tomorrow night. A flash of irrational disappointment registers on Elizabe face, upon being reminded that Forde sees other women.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You do prep?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: For functions. Believe it or not, not everyone hires me for my “skill set”. Half my clients only want me on their arm. Some just wanna sit ‘n talk to someone from a different neck’a the woods, who ain’t gonna judge ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Dear God, that’s pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Functions are different. I gotta be in character. (disdainful) The agency gave me a list’a covers, ‘cause God forbid, I go as a country boy who came to town as a PT. Insurance exec, marketin’ guy. Tomorrow, oil ‘n gas. We get a strong sense that Forde loathes this deceptive a to his work. He is dressed and ready to go; Elizabeth digs an envelope of her handbag, and offers it to him. His bitterness evaporates and he’s back to his playful self.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'll be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I think you owe me somethin’ more.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s all there. Count it.  49.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: This covers my services. But I just gave ya a whole lotta info ‘bout my line’a work. On your principles of exchange... He motions for her to reciprocate.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That was more of a voluntary donation on your part.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: You a real enigma, ya know that? Nothin’ like the typical client.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Old?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Strong. You ain’t here to live out some bizarro fantasy ‘bout bein’ a master or a slave. You’re here for somethin’ else. Elizabeth regards him, ambivalence subdued behind her reflective gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You asked me once what brought me to this room. I guess I’m playing a role too. I pay you so I can imagine a life I chose to forego in pursuit of my career.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Why imagine it, when ya could just go out‘n get it? The question strikes a chord with Elizabeth. She hardens, becomes defensive.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No, it’s not for me. Not when I was in my twenties, and sure as hell not now.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: So no house ya call home, no folks ya call family sorta thing, huh? Ever regret that choice?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not for a second. Forde lets that settle. Peers into her unreadable express

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Well, least now we're peelin’ a layer.  50.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (beat) And that is all my “principles of exchange” will transact. Goodbye, Forde.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Bye, Nothin’. Forde smiles and takes his leave. All business again, Elizabeth shuffles through some docum she’s taken out of her Bottega Veneta briefcase. She stop sets down the file. She sits on the edge of the unkempt b Now, still and silent. Mind distant.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PINEHURST GOLF COURSE, (N. CAROLINA)
dialogues.text: Connors lines up a putt on the green as Bob Sandford and CONGRESSMAN BURNS (50s, even-tempered businessman-turned- politico) look on intently. Connors steadies himself and sinks a fifteen yard putt, nerveless. He pumps his fist, exhilarated by victory.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Fucking A right! His two rivals applaud ruefully. They all shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BURNS
dialogues.text: And there I thought lobbyist etiquette forbids you from beating your client, much less a Congressman. You don’t get to our heart by damaging our fragile egos.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: I'll tell you, Frank, this one here plays by his own rules.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PINEHURST GOLF COURSE, (N. CAROLINA)
dialogues.text: The three now enjoy scotch and a breathtaking view.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BURNS
dialogues.text: I’m a little surprised you even made it out here. The public swings well in favor of gun control, and I’m an the enviable position of financial independence.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: We’re well aware, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BURNS
dialogues.text: I know it may be unusual for a lobbyist to hear, but when I pledged not to accept campaign finance from the Gun Lobby, I meant front and back door.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: We're not offering finance. I know your approval rating’s sky-high. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You could practically vote for Sharia law and you’d still keep your seat. I also know you’re an old school patriot who cares about the future of America. About what America stands for.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BURNS
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with exercising vigilance over who gets their hands on a firearm.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Tell me, Congressman. When I say ‘America’, what’s the first word you think of?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BURNS
dialogues.text: (knowing nod) Freedom.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s in our DNA. And every time this Big Brother, nanny-state makes a new incursion into citizens’ freedoms, it dilutes what makes this country great. Self-sufficiency is celebrated here. You started with nothing and made a fortune buying and leasing aircraft; try doing that in Europe. Everyone in this great nation of ours has it in their power to succeed by their own hand, and everyone has the right to defend what’s theirs.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BURNS
dialogues.text: Some incursions into freedom might be necessary. Heaton-Harris isn’t the end of gun rights.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: No, but it’s a continuation of a culture of erosion. Slowly, they’re taking more and more - slow enough so we won't really feel it over the course of our lifetimes. But ina hundred, two hundred years, what’1l be left of the Second Amendment? Connors’ passion is manifest and genuine. Sandford regard proudly, sipping his scotch and nodding to arguments he doesn’t have the cogency to enunciate. CONNORS (CONT’D) I know you’re not a religious man, so let me put it in evolutionary terms. Fish became amphibians, then reptiles, all the way through primates, and then humans. A monkey didn’t one day give birth to a human baby. But with a series of tiny, imperceptible changes, over millions of years, what started as a fish became something completely different. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONNORS (CONT’D) Sure, Heaton-Harris doesn’t change much on its own. But the cumulative effect of a series of incursions will turn the Second Amendment into something very different to what our Founders intended. Same goes for all of our freedoms. Hell, I’m not here because I love guns; honestly, I don’t. I do love freedom.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BURNS
dialogues.text: Is that not evolution?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Evolution isn’t necessarily positive. Not when we stand to lose one of the things that makes it great to be American: the right to refuse to be a victim. Congressman Burns sighs, looks out at the resplendent fai thinking hard. Opening up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connors walks with Bob Sandford, towards a luxury sedan w has pulled up out front of the club house.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: I never had a great amount of respect for freelance outfits like you. Always figured you're ready to piss whichever way the wind’s blowing to make a buck - that’s why I wanted Sloane. But seeing you at work just now... You really believed what you were saying.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: (firm) I do. Unshakably.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: (beat) Then I’m glad Sloane said No. She did me one helluva favor. He offers his hand to Connors, who shakes it vigorously. BOB SANDFORD (CONT’D) I’ll see you, Pat. Connors nods. Those words meant the world to him. Sandfor gets in the back seat and the car pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the vote count, Congressman Burns’ face gets a BIG RED SLASH stuck over it by Alex, who speaks to colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fuck Monty Burns. We’re sitting on a new five hundred grand. That’s over 12% of our budget.  53.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: It’s now 9.3%!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: It came in anonymously, but everyone’s thinking Bloomberg.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: If you were donating that much, why would you do it anonymously?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: The obvious reason.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What, privacy?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What? No. It makes you look noble when you leak your identity.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Were you born that cynical?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (parroting Elizabeth) There's no such thing as cynicism, only a word to denote the absence-

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Of the naivety I so keenly exhibit, yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara keeps pace with Elizabeth as they quick-step up the stone staircase into the airy and imposing public buildin

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I deleted every vestige of my online existence-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And you didn’t replace it, leaving a Clara-sized hole in Google, which they obviously flagged when they were doing their due diligence. Why’d we lose Burns?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I did replace it. First hit on Clara Thomson gets you a Canadian English teacher in South Korea, but I made a small footprint two rungs down. I’d just returned from a two-year stint with Medcins Sans Frontiers. It was solid.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What can I say? They’re good. Burns. North Carolina. What the hell happened?  54.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: There’s ten of us. How many d’you think we’re up against at Waterman? Thirty? We don’t have the manpower nor the funding to keep up with the Lobby, and we just hadn’t gotten to him yet. They got lucky and picked one who was wide open. Elizabeth grimaces, knowing her point is valid.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unless, of course, it wasn’t luck.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What d’you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: You didn’t tell me about Raj Ama...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Amarasekara. Just call him Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I checked with Finance, he wasn’t paid from the firm’s account. You ran him out of your own pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s good practice to keep your circle small. I needed you sharp with the question in case you slipped through their net, I had nothing to gain by telling you.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: But you had something to lose. You think we might have a leak.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Clara, 25 years in this industry has taught me it’s always best to assume that in this town, no matter where you are, you’re never more than two meters away from a rat. Clara's pace fades, trying to process if there was an implication being made there. Elizabeth strides into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vast main reading room of the world’s biggest library Giant marble columns, bronze statues set high up in the balustrades, and the centerpiece - sunlight seeping throu arch windows beneath a huge, ornate dome. The other eight members of the team work at a reading tab Some have laptops, others scribble on notepads. Elizabeth Clara take their places. Throughout, Clara taps away on h laptop, as if taking notes, not fully invested in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Why are we meeting in a library?  55.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Illinois has six Republicans in the House, a little of this money would go a long way to-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: OK, stop.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: We need to make up 25 votes, I was thinking we contribute to Russell, Stefanovic-

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Screw contributions, we’d be toe-to- toe with the Lobby and we’d lose.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I said stop. ON CLARA’S LAPTOP SCREEN: she sets up a new Facebook acco

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Tell me you haven't already spent it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We’re gonna take this money and use it to send a message. We’re going to swing a state we have absolutely no right to swing.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Please God, don’t say...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Florida. This right here is our turning point.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You’re aware that America now calls Florida “The Gunshine State”?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m being optimistic for a change, I thought you’d approve.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: The whole five hundred grand, gone?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Out the door.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: (in jest) Serves me right for hiring a woman.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Sexism from a Democrat, well I never.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Almost as shocking as you being optimistic.  56.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Look around you. Magnificent architecture, peace, quiet, and every worthwhile text ever published. What’s missing? The team look out at the huge, brilliant space. An OLD GU sleeps at a table nowhere near us. A few TOURISTS walk ar the outskirts, snap photos, mesmerized by the giant dome.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Tumbleweed? This place is a ghost town.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Correct. This is where Mr. and Mrs. Public do not reside. We’re reading fewer books than ever. Persuasion through long-winded argumentation doesn’t work, who has time when we have screens to stare at? Elizabeth aims a pointed look at Clara, whose attention i consumed by her laptop. She eventually looks up at Elizab MASS GROAN. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) We need to market Heaton-Harris the same way they market Big Macs. We're dropping direct mail pamphlets and buying ad space online instead. Alex, you're in charge of the banners, you have a two o’clock with JWT on 14th Street. Now, to the phone banks.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I liked you better as the merchant of doom.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Elizabeth. I’m familiar with the Democrat campaign machinery in Illinois, if I get out there, I can deliver at least two-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I want two phone pitches by end of tomorrow. Clara, Brian, Lauren, you're team one, Cynthia, Esme, Franklin, you’re team two. Ross, provide stats to both. (to Esme) When you’re done here, you get started in Illinois. (to all) Now, the second reason we’re here is that I’d like you all to read Packard's exposé of psychological techniques of commercial advertisers from 1957- "Oh Gods”.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - Which remains dead on point in today’s world of i-nonsense.  57. Clara’s attention is distracted by something on her SCREE friend request from ALEX DE JONG. The message reads: Welcome back to civilization :) ELIZABETH (CONT’D) As you all know, good marketing burrows insidiously into your target’s brain and results in action, for example, buying a Big Mac. Clara glances to Alex, his laptop open in front of him. H gives her a smile, knowing she got the request. Clara not Elizabeth eyeing them, and she expertly recovers:

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Our phone pitch has to “burrow insidiously into Floridian brains?”

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes. And so too your ad banners. They must burrow so deep, your targets are inspired to flood their elected official with pro-Heaton-Harris letters, and use those delightful social networks to implore their friends to do likewise. Now, read the exposé, and take to the media-verse!

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Good thing I’m back on Facebook. Clara didn’t do much to mask her supercilious tone. Alex closes his laptop and gets up, a little smirk on his face It’s not lost on Clara.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Super. Their pompous shareholders can breathe again.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: It’s a public company.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Better still, I can profit personally from your compulsion to tell the world what you ate for breakfast. (sarcastically) I take it all back, God bless e- America. (on her way out) Everyone, get to it!

dialogues.speaker: GUN CONTROL MINI-MONTAGE
dialogues.text: - A strong turnout at a GUN CONTROL MARCH, anti-gun banne waved, alongside pictures of a YOUNG GIRL. - WORKERS plaster the finishing touches on a huge BILLBOA Times Square. ONE KID KILLED BY A GUN EVERY 3 HOURS - A van with a large billboard in its trailer tours a cit center. 150 AMERICANS SHOT DAILY // YOU COULD BE NEXT. - A large and vociferous gathering outside a city hall.  58.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Members of a group called Ceasefire PA rallied outside Senator Jim Mandel’s office in Philadelphia, after a man opened fire in a park, killing a fourteen year-old girl- SENATOR MANDEL stands at a lectern outside his office, an to shout over chants of WE WANT CHANGE.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MANDEL
dialogues.text: I‘1l vote to put the issue of renewed background checks on the Senate floor, and I will support the Heaton- Harris Amendment! The crowd ERUPTS. The Senator beams. Everyone’s happy. - A BIG GREEN TICK is stuck over Senator Mandel's face. - A BIG RED SLASH over another Congressman’s face. Dollar signs drawn in his eyes. A GREEN TICK over another. - 11 VOTES LOCKED, 23 TO GO is scrawled on a whiteboard, underneath - DAYS TO VOTE: 148. INT. POSNER’S OFFICE - DAY - PRESENT Back to present day. A muddle of boxes and files. Posner crosses items off a checklist, while Elizabeth talks to HARRISON (60s), a long-time ally.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Tax avoidance. Any offshore bank accounts, undeclared income?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No. Posner crosses it off. He does this with every new query.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Look, if I'm interrupting, I can-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not at all. What can I do for you, Harrison?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: There’s no more you could possibly do for me, Liz. Look, there’s no easy way to say this-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh, thank God.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You've come to your senses. You’re going to publicly flog me, and about time too.  59.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I was going to use the term “distance ourselves”.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Where’s the fun in that?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I have shareholders to think about. From a PR standpoint... You...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Stop fumbling for a euphemism, Harrison. I’m so toxic I glow in the dark. You're doing absolutely the right thing, and you’ve nothing to apologize for. Elizabeth reaches into a folder, pulls out a stack of pap

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Recreational drug use?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Posner) No! (to Harrison) See these? Cards and letters of apology from clients who felt they had to do the same for the sake of their business. Your corporate spokesman will denounce me in the strongest possible terms. I didn’t help get you where you are only to see you tarnished by this nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: This sucks.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: In your personal capacity as my friend, yes. But you’re not denouncing me as my friend, you're denouncing me as CEO of Harper's, who's duty-bound to act in the best interests of his company. And right now, that entails running from me as fast as you can screaming evil.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: You'll get through this. At that moment, Harrison goes to hug Elizabeth. She’s tak surprise, and panic flashes across her face for a fractio a second. She meets his embrace awkwardly, but begins to into it. She closes her eyes, enjoying a fleeting moment release from the stress of her predicament. The moment lasts a second too long, and Posner can’t help observe a side to Elizabeth he never knew existed. Harrison smiles at her warmly, nods goodbye, and exits.  60.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Never? I mean on the drug use.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh, I thought you were just talking about this morning. No, never. Posner sets down his pen and removes glasses from straine eyes. He takes a moment to regard Elizabeth, who fastidio straightens papers on the desk to regain her composure.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you're OK with your most loyal client stomping on you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He should have done it weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Why don’t you quit? This place?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: I’ve known you long enough now to surmise your feelings toward this city. Sitting in that hearing, listening to them go over your medical records...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (stops; long pause) I wanted to. But I can't. I can’t imagine what in the world I would do. I've been reading The Litigators for the last two years, I haven’t made it past a hundred pages. I’ve gone through eleven doctors, they all want rid of me for ignoring their exhortations to slow down. I want to slow down. But this job is the only means I have of making myself useful. She rests against the desk, stares reflectively upon the cityscape beyond the floor-to-ceiling windows. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Did you know, ideology is dead? The philosophies of the left and right are driven by the self-interest of those who advance them. Elizabeth turns back to Posner, a wistful sadness lingeri behind her tired eyes. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Neither side cares for the merits of their argument; they just happen to spout it because it suits their position in the world. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (CONT’D) They'd switch in a heartbeat if a millionaire lost everything, or a broke socialist won the lottery, or better still, earned a fortune by their own hand. People have no real ideology. All their political proclamations are governed solely by

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: That would include you?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Behind all of my conscious brain's grandstanding, I would think so. I don’t know why, but part of me wishes I hadn’t ever realized that. A meaningful silence overtakes the room. They both gaze u the dusking sun. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Elizabeth. Elizabeth gently swivels her neck to face him. Takes in h sincere expression. A touch flattered he knew of the occa

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Thank you, Daniel. She returns her rueful stare to the high-powered world sprawled out beyond the glass. And softly exhales.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Elizabeth marches down the sidewalk towards Peterson Wyat office and unloads into her cell phone. Rodolfo Schmidt b a lung to catch up to her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Gunshot victims cost the American taxpayer $12 billion a year. That's $32 per gun in circulation. Now get your house in order. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Liz Sloane, making a stand for the taxpayer, even from the left.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Come off it. Heaton-Harris might get three guns out of the hands of three psychopaths, but the gun injury horse has long bolted.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Was it ever in the stable?  62.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: David Badgley, Senator from Michigan. Came out in support months ago, but he just gave a quote saying now he wants to “wait and see”. His PAC received twenty-five grand from the Gun Lobby two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: A one-eighty.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: “Wait and see” were his words, so it’s really more like a ninety.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We have him on celluloid pledging his support?

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Bang to rights.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So we'll just have to make him feel it. Grand unveiling - you coming?

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I have a con-call.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Make them wait. glimmer in eye) You’1l want to see this. They enter the modern, glassy office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team sit around the table, and flip through tabbed bi of documents, which contain sample AD BANNERS, PHONE PITC SCRIPTS, and verification materials.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Alex, these are... Good!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: They're burrowing insidiously into your brains as you read.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Hold on, the numbers are wrong. The House delegations, Florida has 27-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We’re not going to Florida.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Florida’s out.  63.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: But you said, we’re gonna swing Florida, isn’t that what this is-

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Turn to Tab Twelve, please. They do. Team members remove an ENVELOPE, and take out wh appear to be photos. Faces go blank.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I don’t have anything at Tab Twelve- Cynthia peers over at Brian’s photos - long distance shot telephoto lens - Cynthia meets Connors on a park bench. Rodolfo is already on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Security, we’re in Cl, get in here. Lock down Cynthia Green’s office, secure her files and hard drives, and escort her off the premises. He hangs up. To Cynthia:

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Your Blackberry, now. Cynthia is speechless. Rodolfo HAMMERS his fist on temper glass.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Now! Cynthia fumbles her Blackberry onto the table. SECURITY GUARDS enter.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: He offered me a partnership track...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Good luck with that. Cynthia is escorted out of the room. Rodolfo tosses the p onto the table in front of Elizabeth, and follows them ou

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth; exiting) We'll talk later.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: The whole Florida thing was a ruse?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m not that optimistic. But the Gun Lobby just bought a cabal of Floridian Congressmen they owned all along, while we’re about to emerge from left field and sweep Colorado before they can figure out what hole they just got screwed in.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: We're taking this to Colorado?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You have tonight to re-write your pitches. Get to it. The entire team SCRAMBLES - half of them turn straight to Ross, and ask for stats and info.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Eeeuuuugggghhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inside of a van has been transformed into a mobile surveillance unit. Elizabeth introduces Rodolfo to BIG SA LITTLE SAM, who sit at home with high-end equipment.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Meet my unofficial support team.

dialogues.speaker: BIG SAM
dialogues.text: Hi. Call me Big Sam.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SAM
dialogues.text: Little Sam.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I'd introduce myself, but judging by this set-up, you may already know me very well.

dialogues.speaker: BIG SAM
dialogues.text: There are six of us, four are out on assignment.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: And you’re ex..?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So Badgley’s flip-flopping. In my experience, the quickest way to bring him in line is to mine for sordid details and let him know we’re in possession of them.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: What exactly are you gentlemen capable of?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SAM
dialogues.text: Standard 24-hour audio and video surveillance, cell phone and online account hacking, financial transactions, location tracking, and, with our latest tech, close-quarters audio, anytime, any place.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: How’d you manage that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the expression ‘a fly on the wall’? We’re not that small yet, but... 65. Little Sam reaches for a plastic container for a small pe perhaps a lizard or a gerbil. He pulls out a COCKROACH.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SAM
dialogues.text: Meet the cutting edge in eavesdropping.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: It’s a cockroach.

dialogues.speaker: BIG SAM
dialogues.text: Yes. It can be retro-fitted as a cybernetic robo-roach with this. Big Sam holds up a tiny ‘electronic backpack’.

dialogues.speaker: BIG SAM
dialogues.text: We glue electrodes to the legs, perforate its thorax, and we can control its movement remotely.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Don't call PETA, Schmidt.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SAM
dialogues.text: Incorporated into the backpack is a class A listening device. Gone are the days of manual bugging. These guys can crawl under doors, into crevices, bags, cars, undetected. They can go without food for weeks and still be mobile.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: My God...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If there’s anything in his life worth excavating, these guys won’t take long to get it.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: It’s mind-boggling, ingenious, and completely unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Booooo.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You're talking about blackmailing a member of Congress, and I won’t entertain it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're only here because I figured you might say that. Rodolfo regards her. Is she testing his ethics?  66.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Now, I appreciate that you often employ more creative tactics - to great effect, I might add - and, without prejudice to the undoubtedly stellar job you guys do... Our firm has certain standards below which we're simply not prepared to stoop.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Rodolfo. I wouldn’t have it any other way. Now she regards him. He is a different animal than George Dupont.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Good. Find an alternative. Rodolfo Schmidt exits the van. Elizabeth makes a phone ca

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Johnny! Liz. I’m going to need the largest inflatable rat you've got. INT. “INFLATABLES R US” STORE - DAY - PAST Elizabeth and Clara walk through a maze of inflated superheroes on display for moms planning a garden party.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: You knew there was a leak from when?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I had my suspicions after the AMA fundraiser.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: And you had her watched? By a PI?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That’s right. Ah, here we are. They arrive at a GIANT INFLATABLE RAT. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Say hello to Senator Badgley’s new best friend. (calls out) Johnny! Wrap it up!

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: How did you know it was her?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: The leak - you had Cynthia watched, how did you know it was her?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I didn’t. I had you all watched. Elizabeth walks off.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Influential figures from business and politics rub should and clink champagne flutes. The placard at the entrance t us we're at a charity dinner for the prevention of sexual violence in conflict. The disconnect is glaring. FORDE stands in a small circle of ATTENDEES with his CLIE Vera Wang-clad corporate career woman in her 30s. His pos and demeanor are different here; in character, he is poli and gentlemanly. He fits right in.

dialogues.speaker: MALE ATTENDEE
dialogues.text: So we reached the 18th, and I knew all I needed was par to win-

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I thought the golden rule was to never beat your client?

dialogues.speaker: MALE ATTENDEE
dialogues.text: Exactly! But he tees off and shanks it into the boonies, how the hell am I not gonna win this?! Polite LAUGHTER from the circle.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ATTENDEE
dialogues.text: (to Forde) Calvin, do you get the chance to golf down in Austin?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Not nearly as much as I'd like to. I got a set of Titleist irons gathering dust in my garage. All the gear, and no idea. More phoney LAUGHTER. Forde’s client touches him on the a

dialogues.speaker: CLIENT
dialogues.text: Excuse me a moment, dear. She goes to the ladies’ room. Forde’s eye catches somethi and he peels off from the circle after perfunctory farewe ELSEWHERE in the ballroom, Elizabeth empties a glass of champagne and returns the flute to a passing waiter.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Howdy. Cal Sneider, I’m in banking and actuarial. You know, you look familiar to me... Elizabeth regards him with no recognition whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I think you have the wrong person. She moves away, uncomfortable. He pursues.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: You can do better than that.  68.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (cold) Really, Mr. Sneider, I’ve no idea who you think I am. Excuse me. She walks away. Forde watches her go, bemused. FROM A CORNER of the ballroom, R.M. Dutton has observed t whole exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connors watches the TV, pissed. ON THE TV - CONGRESSMAN BADGLEY of Michigan fights through press and anti-gun protesters in the shadow of a GIANT RAT.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: I can’t fucking believe they’re showing - can you fucking believe - I don't fucking believe.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Eight of the top ten national news outlets are running it.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: She’s bought them - she’s bought the whole goddam-—

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: She doesn’t need to buy them, they swing left all on their own.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: He took that twenty-five grand, we need to make it crystal clear to him what happens if he backs down.

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: I think someone just beat us to it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It has its own Twitter feed.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dejected Congressman Badgley sits through a strategy me with his SPIN DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: SPIN DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Every day that thing follows you around, the more people at the protests, the more voters are- They're both distracted by the ominous specter of a giant EAR, visible in the window. It ‘waddles’ outside througho big stupid grin on its face.  69.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BADGLEY
dialogues.text: How do we get this fucking thing out of my face?

dialogues.speaker: SPIN DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Ride it out. Might take weeks. Enough time to forge a career-long association between you and a giant rodent. Or you can clarify your position on Heaton-Harris.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN BADGLEY
dialogues.text: Can I just stick a knife in it?

dialogues.speaker: SPIN DOCTOR
dialogues.text: If you want the entire news cycle to yourself, be my guest. Congressman Badgley buries his head in his hands and SIGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAP. Congressman Badgley’s mugshot is the latest to get green tick stuck over it. SLOWLY PULL BACK to reveal the team working quietly, efficiently. Brian, who just stuck on the tick, talks on cell and updates the whiteboard to: DAYS TO VOTE: 98. 18 VOTES LOCKED, 16 TO GO.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You know we're not supposed to be having this conversation, right? CROSS-CUT between Brian, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, having her make-up done, hating every second. INTERCUT with strategy room where necessary:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: There’s no way in hell Rosen is tacking on his Assault Weapons Ban to Heaton-Harris.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: It’s kind of flattering he sees it as a moving train though, right? Rodolfo Schmidt sees Brian on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Is that her? Busted, Brian hands it over. RODOLFO SCHMIDT (INTO PHONE) (CONT’D) I thought we agreed you’d focus on the debate, for just thirty minutes-—  70.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: The Assault Weapons Ban is a vote- winning ploy which sounds appealing to the uninformed. It’s Potemkin legislation designed to help Rosen keep his hand in the cookie jar. It doesn’t help people, it helps him.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Banning assault weapons doesn’t help people? Say, people who might otherwise have been victims of assault weapons?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You rest my case on the ‘uninformed’. All guns are assault weapons, the AWB bans cosmetic features like pistol grips. I don’t remember too many gun victims being beaten to death with a telescoping stock. The sum total of the AWB is that it makes gun-wielding lunatics look a little less scary as they kill people.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I see you’re in the mood for war, that’s good. Focus on the debate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connors sits in stone-faced silence. ANDERSON COOPER smil him amiably, but Connors stonewalls him, clearly not a fa Elizabeth steps onto set. Harsh lighting already annoying

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Liz! If you’re thinking I’m gonna go easy, I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER
dialogues.text: Ms. Sloane, please, take a-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Connors) Making bullshit job offers to my staff, you’ve plumbed new depths.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: The student becomes the master.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Really? How much did you spend again to secure Florida?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: You taught me how to control a Congressional office. Offer to double their chief of staff’s money when his term’s up, he’s all yours-—

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That's different. You just ruined that young lady’s career.  71.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Me? She’s not paying for her bad call? Or does individual responsibility no longer exist? You really have gone soft and liberal.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Live in four, three, two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed house, popcorn being consumed by the bucket. ON TV

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER
dialogues.text: Hello, and welcome to this special edition of Anderson Cooper 360.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: You used to work with this guy?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Connors? Yeah. Loud, foul-mouthed, and very effective.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: But she can take him, right?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Put it this way: I wouldn’t want to be either of the men at that table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-debate. Anderson Cooper, little more than a spectator looks like he hasn’t blinked in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: This is the latest incursion into individual liberty by an all-powerful federal government-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What, like drivers’ licenses?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Drivers’ licenses? I’m not really seeing the connection.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It's illegal to operate a car without going through rigorous theoretical and practical assessments, that’s a clear constraint on the freedom of individuals to drive cars, as with pilots to fly planes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Fugu chefs. Come on. Fugu chefs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cluttered campaign office. Esme and a group of STAFFERS takeout, glued to the TV.  72.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: In Japan, chefs have to train for seven years before they’re allowed to serve a poisonous blowfish called fugu-

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER
dialogues.text: We're deviating slightly off topic-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Do you think the government should abolish drivers’ licences? Esme can’t suppress her smile as Elizabeth cuts into Conn about to twist the knife.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Of course not-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why, they’re a government incursion on individual liberty, are they not? We accept them because they make sense; the more dangerous the machinery, the more rigorous the tests should be. We wouldn’t want unfit drivers in cars any more than novice pilots flying 747s, because dangerous machinery in the wrong hands poses a threat to public safety. I think we can extend our definition of ‘dangerous machinery’ to semi-automatic firearms.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: That’s his cue...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Go on, bite you son-of-a-bitch.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: The Second Amendment to the Constitution doesn’t guarantee the right to drive cars, it guarantees the right to keep and bear arms. CHEERS from members of the team. Alex and Clara hi-five.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Boom!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The Second Amendment was signed in a time where the average life expectancy was 38, and the population of the largest city in America would fit inside the Orange Bowl. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What may have been perfectly sensible in those alien times is wholly inadequate to solve the problems of the present.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: The Constitution is the highest legal document in the land, it’s unimpeachable and explicit, ‘the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed.’

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nothing is unimpeachable, not even the Constitution. The clue lies in the title of the very legislation you’re so quick to parrot.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER
dialogues.text: Hold on Liz, now that’s a very forceful argument; the wording of the Second Amendment is explicit-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Really? Do you find it forceful?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER
dialogues.text: Well, ah, I’m just saying, a lot of people would-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Because I find it the weakest, most mind-numbing retort in their arsenal; sort of a last refuge for those with no real argument at all-

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: You're talking about the United States Constitution-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And I can’t stand to see people hide behind it just as they hide behind the Bible to deny gay people rights. Literalists need to stop reciting their sacred parchments and exercise their brain power. If they can produce a rational winning argument, I'll gladly migrate to their side, but ‘because it says so in the Constitution, the Bible, or my horoscope’ is not a winning argument. It’s a ripcord; the intellectual equivalent of a yellow, pant-pissing wimp cowering behind mommy's skirt. Deathly silence. Elizabeth and Connors eyeball each other

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER
dialogues.text: OK, time out! We’re going for a break, and when we come back, maybe these two will stop playing so nice and the gloves’1ll really come off.  74.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Connors) Still think I’ve gone soft?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. Everyone has gone home. Elizabeth kicks her shoes, reclines in a chair and reads The Washington P Rodolfo Schmidt approaches, catches her unaware.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You ever sleep?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not when I’m 16 votes short. (re: Washington Post) This sometimes does the trick.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You put on quite a show.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He had it coming.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You really believe Heaton-Harris is going to make a big difference...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: America’s awash with guns. They’re a art of our culture, that’s irreversible. But the stakes are such that Heaton-Harris doesn’t need to make a big difference. If it keeps one gun out of the hands of one lunatic, that could be the difference between the life and death of an innocent civilian. And all our work would have been worth it.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Did you know someone..? Someone who was a victim of gun-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No, why does everybody assume that? It’s insulting.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: It’s not insulting, it’s-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It's insulting, it implies I can only see the merits of an argument when I feel the effects personally. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There was a Congressman, I forget his name - spent his entire career opposing gay rights, only to do a U- turn when his brother came out. How absurd is that? His whole life, it’s disgusting and he’s against it, but suddenly it’s OK because his brother does it? What a well-reasoned basis for an opinion. Quick, someone give this man a gavel and put him ina courthouse!

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I see you’re still in kill mode.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I only have one setting, you should know that by now.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Well, then I‘'1l just say I didn’t mean to insult you and leave it at that. Rodolfo steps to the door, but stops -

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Liz? (beat) Thank you for doing this. They regard one another before he takes his leave. The sentiment lingers behind her softening eyes. Then she thr The Washington Post back up into her line of vision as we CUT TO BLACK. A moment’s silence.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Caller --

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Clara Thomson

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Has entered the conference.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sits sentry outside a fancy restaurant, phone to his Gaze firmly fixed on the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey. We’re the first two on, I guess we're a little early. Intercut as necessary with --  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A popular donuts and coffee chain. Clara sits at a table, plugged into her laptop, stacks of papers in front of her

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey! OK, ah - d’you want me to dial back in a couple minutes?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You kidding? I’m going out of my mind here. I should have been a sports agent. This guy’s been at lunch for the last two hours. Lunch is literally his job.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: That can’t be good for your waistline. What’s he look like? Alex flips open a file and regards a bio mugshot of a fat porcine SPORTS AGENT.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You have a point. (deep breath) Anyway, while we’re on that topic... One of these days, if you’re not too busy, I was thinking maybe we could-

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Caller --

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: (sarcastic deadpan) The Easter Bunny and her Merry Little Helper.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Has entered the conference. THREE-WAY INTERCUT with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Rodolfo Schmidt hover over a conference pho speaker.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Who do we have so far?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Me and Clara. (quick correction) Clara and I.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey guys. Let’s give it a couple minutes then.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: (playful) Alex, why don’t you go ahead and finish your thought? Maybe we could..?  77.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: (panic; in a bind) I was just spit-balling, ah, maybe we could - go see Mel Whitman, Congressman Perez's chief of staff, lock up his vote once and for all-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: The same Perez who appeared on Good Morning America last week, beating the Heaton-Harris drum? I hardly think that’s the best use of your time. Speaking of which, what the hell are you two-

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Caller --

dialogues.speaker: ESME, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Esme Manucharian.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Has entered the conference. FOUR-WAY INTERCUT with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esme is on both her cell and a landline intermittently, a shouts over the DIN of CROSS-TALK and RINGING PHONES in t campaign boiler room.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: (into landline) Hold just a second please. (into cell) Illinois says hi, guys. We're gaining, I’m doing the rounds on local TV, I’m on again tomorrow morning. Rumor out of Perry’s camp is that he’s gonna come out in favor early next week.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Sounds like time well spent. Clara?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: In a Donut Factory, going over polling data.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: In a Donut Factory?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You know, with Joe and Jane Public?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Very well. Alex?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Getting nothing from sports agents. None wanna stick their heads above the parapet ‘cause it’ll limit their clients’ commercial appeal. Apparently, we’re not cool enough.  78.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Where are you now?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Waiting for Seth Leventhal to roll his fat ass out of Mario’s Trattoria. Been trying to set up a meeting with this pear-shaped bastard all last week, so now I’m just gonna ambush him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hold off. The solution’s right there. If Heaton-Harris isn’t cool enough-

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Caller --

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Hel -- Hello? How do I get this thing to w-

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Has entered the conference. FIVE-WAY INTERCUT with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross speaks into a cell phone while Franklin conducts pedestrian surveys in this crowded shopping thoroughfare.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello? We’re here!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Ross, let me guess: your highly complex and refined survey of American youth is about to tell us that Heaton-Harris isn’t cool enough.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Quite the understatement. Listen to this... Ross puts his phone on speaker and accosts a SHOPPER (20s

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, are you in favor of more thorough background checks for gun owners?

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPER
dialogues.text: Yeah, definitely, with everything that’s going on with all the, like, shootings and stuff-

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of the Heaton- Harris Amendment?

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPER
dialogues.text: That a colon cleanser?  79.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Thank you, that’s all I needed. (into phone) You get that?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Alex, if it’s not cool enough, the solution is to make it cooler. Your agents would talk their sports-star clients into endorsing it all by themselves. Where the hell’s Brian when you need-

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Caller --

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Brian and Lauren here.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED TELEPHONE VOICE, (FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Has entered the conference. SIX-WAY INTERCUT, with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and Lauren sit with two EDITORS in a cutting room, sharing a headphone each and the phone receiver.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey guys, the TV spot’s almost done. We'll be good to submit it to the NFL for opening day clearance by the end of the week.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Good. Now we’re all here, let’s get to it. Ross?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Levels of support aren’t the problem, the problem is that we’re not reaching enough people, so support doesn't translate into action.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Our message is good. We just need a big enough platform to blast it out so that everyone can hear it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Any of our friends in the media will tell you that’s only accomplished with scandal and controversy. Our message isn’t penetrating to younger voters, most of whom are pro, but few of whom are politically active. In short, we need to make gun control cool. Brian, you have a background in marketing.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: We could use a meme. Like a slogan, a unit of cultural-  80.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I’ve read Dawkins, I know what a meme is.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You don’t reach these guys with direct mail pamphlets. Brian notices that a hip young Editor beside him is engro in her phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: You reach them on their smart phones. IN THE DONUT FACTORY, Clara listens to the conversation w staring into her laptop SCREEN: Alex’s friend request rem unanswered. The cursor hovers above ACCEPT. She hits it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Let's do it. They’re young, gullible, easily manipulated, and move in herds. ON THE BENCH, Alex half-listens, on his tablet. Something his screen gets his attention - Clara’s Facebook notifica Alex smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: So what’s our meme? Crickets.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Alright, I’m no good at platitudes, but we have at least four democrats on the team. You’re supposed to be all creative. Come up with something. She flicks off the speaker phone, abruptly ending the cal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross, Alex, Clara, Brian, and Franklin sit around the tab bereft of ideas. Ross writes something in his notebook. Everyone looks at him eagerly. He notices.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: No, I’m just reminding myself to buy a new toothbrush.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: Now there’s empty pizza boxes and beer bottles littered a the table. Esme is on speaker phone:

dialogues.speaker: ESME, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Here’s what I got: most people are pro-Heaton-Harris, but in their minds only. If they want change, they need to get politically active, maybe for the first time in their lives. They need to get loud. Therefore... #GetLoud.  81.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Talk is cheap; it’s actions that count. Change is brought about not by words but by actions: letters, petitions, marching on town halls. It's kinda long, but... Actions Speak Louder Than Guns.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: How about this: eighty percent say they want change, but how many are prepared to do something about it? How many are prepared to be the change? It's a quote from Gandhi. Be the change that you wish to see in the world. #BeTheChange.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That one makes me want to puke more than the other two put together. They look to Elizabeth, hovering in the background.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Really? You don’t like it?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Don’t like it? I despise it with every fiber of my being. We're running with that one. INT. PETERSON WYATT - RODOLFO’S OFFICE - DAY - PAST Rodolfo works quietly at his desk, while Elizabeth sits o couch, on her cell, mid-rant:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: We've crafted the message already, and yes, it conforms to the word limit for the attentionally challenged youth of today. (listens) Of course not, I got one of our cool people to do it. (listens) No Ari, not Matt Damon. We’ve already got the Damon crowd, we want the Timberlake crowd. (listens) Not politically interested but all too willing to board a bandwagon. (listens) Beaver? Look, get him too. Get as many taste-makers as you can to regurgitate it. Re-tweet, whatever, just herd the damn sheep, would you? She hangs up on him. Immediately starts making another ca Rodolfo smirks and shakes his head a little.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (TO RODOLFO)
dialogues.text: What? Rodolfo just shrugs. Someone answers Elizabeth's call:  82.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Tracey Jacobs, please. (listens) Liz Sloane. As she waits, Elizabeth glances over to Rodolfo again, an notices a framed photo on his desk: Rodolfo and his wife close friends at a ski resort in Chamonix. Mont Blanc tow over them in the background. The group stand tight, skis buried in powder; all look re and happy. Elizabeth's face softens, pensive. Someone picks up and she SNAPS back to reality. Moment ov

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Tracey, hi. I’m fine. I need you to make some calls.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: - Justin Timberlake’s Twitter page. #BeTheChange is all w need to see. Other celebrities follow suit. - ‘Retweet’ and ‘Favorite’ are clicked repeatedly. - FACEBOOK pages light up with gun control posts and imag - NATIONAL TRENDS - #BeTheChange is first on the list. - A bevy of American sports stars’ Twitter pages blitz th cause. Kobe Bryant, Kevin Durant, LeBron James, Derek Jet Tom Brady implore their legions of followers to #BeTheCha - The pedestrian area in Times Square is chock-full as protesters clutching BE THE CHANGE banners and placards merrily CHANT the mantra and soak in summer sunshine. - AT AN ANONYMOUS TOWN HALL, a dusty old book rests on a plinth beneath a sign that reads PUBLIC PETITIONS. A wear eyed JANITOR trudges in and gets a shock - members of the public (some wear Be The Change T-shirts), male and femal young and old, are queuing out the door to sign the book. - SLAP SLAP SLAP. A glut of green ticks plastered over Congressmen’s faces. - The whiteboard reads DAYS TO VOTE: 76. A HAND erases th numbers in 18 VOTES LOCKED, 16 TO GO and updates them - 2 VOTES LOCKED, 12 TO GO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pro-gun team (Ramirez, Travis, Wickham, Moore, Jane, Dutton and a few more JUNIORS) endure a Connors tirade.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Be the change, be the change, I see this bullshit everywhere I go. They're walking all over us! We need to counter this crap, right the fuck now. Tell me one person in this room has something. Silence. Heads down.  83.

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: You got something?

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Got nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RAMIREZ
dialogues.text: This ain’t fair. They got lefties on their team, they’re good at all that creative shit.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: I'd like to see one of those fuckwits in a bar fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and Clara eat takeout and shoot the shit.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: You think we ought to prepare for a counter? I mean, we’re wide open. They could just make Be The Change into Beat The Change, as in, beat the amendment.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Pull the trigger on gun control?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Heaton-Harris is... Heathen malice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blank stares all round.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Anything... Anybody...

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: No dilution of the Constitution.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Control criminals, not guns.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: So what d’you think? Should we prep counters for some of these? Both consider for a second. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connors snaps, breaks the silence.  84.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Alright, fuck this. We’re gonna spend big on TV spots, I want Clint Eastwood directing Chuck Norris, no expense spared. The whole room breathes a SIGH of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth enters and closes the door softly behind her. I bucketing rain outside and she’s half-soaked. Forde sits at the desk and looks out the window at the de He turns to She grabs a look at her.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: You’re Madeline Elizabeth Sloane. You work in government affairs at a communications company.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well, hooray for Google. “Government affairs” and “communications” are just fancy words for lobbying. The only person to ever call me Madeline was my mother. towel and dries her hair, unperturbed.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: What was that? The other night? You pretended like we were strangers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: In public, we are.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: We were alone-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: In a room full of Washington's finest. I can’t be associated with you there, at least one other person knew the truth about you. It wasn’t intended, but Forde is a little hurt by this.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I hear you lobbyists ain’t so good with truth.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Says who? The man with four identities, who sleeps with strangers for money? Elizabeth regrets that instantly. There is a moment’s sil as Forde is again reminded of his status as a leper.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I work at my covers. I was just surprised how much of a natural you are. The way you just switched? You need to teach me how to do that.  85.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Decades of experience. Forde, deception is an integral part of social interaction. The average man lies six times a day, women three.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: So I experienced.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So what’s the problem?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: No problem. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You know, you just uttered the most common lie told by both sexes.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Alright. It’s wrong. Satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That’s a little simplistic.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Guess I’m a simple guy.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why then do you lie for a living?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Pays the bills faster than showin’ “Washington’s finest” how to use a stairmaster.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There are degrees of wrongness. Immoral as a harmless lie may be, it may be perfectly moral to tell a hundred of them to prevent a truly pernicious outcome. Lies and half- truths are a lobbyist’s stock in trade. But I’ve never deployed one for a cause I didn’t believe in.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: (defeated shrug; beat) So... We gettin’ down to business or what? Elizabeth hesitates. Things have changed. Her secret is o and she no longer feels the need to be curt with him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are you hungry? I wouldn’t mind... Just ordering room service tonight. Forde looks at her, intrigued. He straightens out, for th first time with her feeling like he’s a respectable human not a support system for his manhood. LATER - Elizabeth and Forde sit over room service.  86.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: You once told me this was pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If you were a total stranger, it would be.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Your line of work... It’s all ‘bout reputation, right? Nobody’s gonna cut ya any slack if they got dirt on you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Dirt has been known to end careers in this town, yes.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: (smiles) I must be worth somethin’... You're takin’ quite a risk, bein’ here.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It would only be a risk if I didn’t trust your discretion. But I must say, I didn’t expect you to be quite so... Principled. Elizabeth chuckles to herself sarcastically. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) You know, this is the closest I've ever come to a date?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: You never been on a date?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I went about my business and got on with my professional life; I took the view that if I ever stumbled upon it, I'd explore it. But I never sought it out. Nor did I ‘stumble upon it’. So, here we are.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: What’d you do in college? Don’t tell me you were-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Studying, which is, after all, the objective of college.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: It's fair to say you ‘n me had very different objectives. Elizabeth adjusts her Patek Philippe watch, regards it. Retreats inside herself for a softened beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (slows down) You know, I’m not from money. Quite the opposite, in fact. Not many people know that.  87.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Can't say I ever thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: When you’re growing up as an only child, and you and your single mother sleep together on the floor ‘cause she can't afford a bed... Let’s just say it focuses you. Distractions like relationships pale into insignificance.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: You don’t get lonely?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I've no time to get lonely. Speaking of which... Elizabeth reaches into her handbag and pulls out an envel Hands it to Elizabeth's defensive. Forde. He does not take it.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: For what? Tonight’s my night off.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What d’you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I didn’t work tonight. I had dinner with a friend. As it would happen, a single, female friend. Maybe next time we can get together for that coffee ya were so quick to shoot down. demeanor changes. She withdraws, becomes

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No. Don’t be ridiculous. Take it.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Fair exchange without. You got my company, I got yours.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Damn it, Forde, take the fucking money. He pauses. Realizes she isn’t yet ready for this to be personal. Always business.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Suit y’erself. He takes the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: BUS, ILLINOIS
dialogues.text: Esme sits near the back among weary COMMUTERS after a har day’s work. Nobody even She taps at her phone robotically. Nobody talks. looks at anyone else.  88. The bus stops and new passengers get on. A MIDDLE-AGED MA gets up and offers his seat to a LADY who can’t be much o than him.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED MAN
dialogues.text: (looks down) But for how much longer in those? She’s wearing a clunky pair of heels to his comfy Air Max Conceding, the Lady smiles and takes a seat. The Middle-A Man steps closer to the front of the bus. Esme lowers her phone, and rests her head softly against window. She’s just closing her eyes, when -- A SCUFFLE breaks out near the front of the bus. Esme cran her neck to see what all the fuss is about --

dialogues.speaker: AN ERRANT GUNSHOT RINGS OUT
dialogues.text: People SCREAM. Some hit the deck - some are thrown off-ba as the bus SCREECHES to a halt. A guy with a BUZZ CUT (20s) barges his way through commut in his hand - A FN HERSTAL 5.7 - He’s on a beeline, fixing his determined glare squarely O ESME - he strides with purpose right for her. She realizes and tries to scramble out of her seat - Buzz Cut raises the gun -— He has a clean shot. All he has to do is pull the trigg--

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: Buzz Cut JOLTS forward, hit twice in the back. His FN Her drops to the floor behind him, skidding to a pair of firm planted Air Max 90s. BLOOD appears at the corner of his m and he collapses, dead. Behind him stands the Middle-Aged Man who offered his sea stern expression behind a smoking Glock 9. Rock-solid sta of someone who spends a lot of time at the firing range. name is FRANK MCGILL. Like a pro, he kicks the fallen FN Herstal out of Buzz Cu reach. Only then does he glance up. Esme is on the floor, pressed up against a seat. She shiv in shock. Her watered eyes meet the focused stare of her savior.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO BLACK
dialogues.text: INT. CONNORS’ HOUSE - DAY - PAST Morning in the Connors household. His WIFE and obnoxious KIDS are at the breakfast table. Connors has his phone to ear, and is glued to a TV NEWS REPORT. On the phone:  89.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m getting it.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (VIA T.V.)
dialogues.text: We understand the assailant was a firearms enthusiast, and was targeting a leading figure in the gun control movement, who was traveling as a passenger on the bus. The assailant was then shot dead himself by a civilian passenger who was carrying a registered concealed firearm. Two people were rushed to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries in an incident that could’ve been much worse had this brave man not...

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: George? You there? Get ready to spend some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A secluded spot that feels like a million miles from civilization. Sunlight filters through treetops and all t can be heard is the electric BUZZ of cicadas. Esme sits on a bench. She stares into space, lifeless. She doesn’t so much as turn her head when Elizabeth sits to her, softly. Elizabeth sets down her carry-on, clearly fresh from a plane. The pair don’t look at each other for a while. Elizabeth her time here, not her usual belligerent self.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: All the time I spend in the city, somehow I’m still more comfortable here.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, we had a family get- together... We were sitting around the table at breakfast, talking about what animal we'd be if we were reincarnated. Some said birds. My uncle wanted to be a hippo, wallowing in mud all day. When my turn came, I thought I'd be clever. I said ‘human’. Over the next twenty years, I slowly realized everyone else at that table had already considered that option and ruled it out.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I had a look at your staff profile. You're one of the most prominent anti- gun campaigners in D.C. You went to high school in Colorado in the late ‘90s. The name of the school isn’t stated.  90. She hasn't looked at her yet, but Esme gives Elizabeth th tiniest of nods to confirm her suspicion. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: I locked myself in a classroom and hid under a desk. I covered my ears, but it did nothing. People were dying outside. I heard knocks on the door.
