I didn’t have it in me to even try to help. I couldn’t move... I never wanted to feel that way again. She gazes upon the verdant landscape; her eyes moistening composure weakening. ESME (CONT’D) Yesterday... Yesterday, I felt the exact same way I did when I was eighteen. I got very good at acting tough, but nothing changed underneath. Nothing really changes at all. Elizabeth spends a moment digesting her words. Her intona slower, more considered here.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You may find this hard to believe, but I’m no stranger to those sentiments myself.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: You were involved in a shooting?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (beat) No. But I spent much of my formative years with my hands over my ears, trying, and failing absolutely, to block out the sounds of my father beating my mother. Esme looks at Elizabeth. It’s the first time she’s ever h anything from her that isn’t work-related. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Eventually, there came a point at which I could no longer tolerate it. Brave or stupid, one day, when he got violent, I stood up to him. When you grow up in fear of someone, they hold a certain power over you that subsists, regardless of your age or relative strength. But that first time, at the age of fourteen? That was the hardest thing I’ve done by a distance.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: ... What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It took him by surprise. The immediate backlash for me wasn't pretty... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: but he wasn’t so quick to get violent the next time. That stand changed everything. When he did take his swings, my mother and I stood up to him together. Ultimately, it gave us the confidence to run away from the bastard and never look back. It wasn’t an inspiring ending, by any stretch, but some battles, believe it or not, are best won by turning your back. And some can only be won by not backing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth regards Esme, not as a subordinate or even a colleague, but more like a proud parent. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) It’s oh-so-easy to keep your mouth shut and let it slide, but you and I both managed to find that courage inside of us. Especially you, Esme. And when one person nails their colors to the mast, you’1ll find that others will be quick to follow. That’s how change happens. Esme retains her sense of despondency, but on some level is buoyed by Elizabeth's showing of respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Frank McGill is held up as an all-American hero. - McGill graces the covers of newspapers and magazines, holding up his Glock 9. - He receives an award from a city OFFICIAL. Flashbulbs P - POSTERS are stuck on windows, car bumpers. McGill point Glock at us. OUTLAW GUNS AND ONLY OUTLAWS WILL HAVE GUNS. another poster, a whole crowd of Frank McGills with guns their hips. LET’S ALL BE FRANK. PROTECT YOUR COMMUNITY. - SLAP SLAP SLAP. Red slashes plastered over mugshots. - ON THE WHITEBOARD - DAYS TO VOTE: 42. The vote count re 25 VOTES LOCKED, 9 TO GO. The numbers are replaced: 21 VO LOCKED, 13 TO GO. The team’s now losing ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team works in the usual melee of RINGING PHONES and C TALK. Esme steps in and the room falls silent. People sto what they’re doing. Elizabeth lowers a phone from her ear her eyes meet Esme’s. She scans the silenced room. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: We're losing ground. What can I do? Moment over. Esme is surrounded by colleagues, updating h and asking for her input. Ross sidles up to her, sheepish

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: How are you doing?  92.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: I’m okay. An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: D’you know the statistical likelihood of being struck by lightening twice?

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: (a bit annoyed) No, Ross, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: -.. Neither do I. They finally share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and the team are morose, quiet. They sit and wa Brian gets off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: OK, thank you. Bye. (hangs up) That was the advertising standards division of the NFL. Our TV spot was rejected.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (indignant) What?! How can they do that?!

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: We now fall foul of the ‘extreme political sensitivity’ clause.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Bloomberg funded anti-gun spots during last year’s superbowl-

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Not right after Frank McGill. The killer blow. A brief moment’s silence, until -- Ross enters. Everyone straightens out.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: OK, so it’s not great. Finance was tailing off anyway, but on current projections, we can afford phone-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Let’s get to the point. With our best foot forward, based on your best guess, how do things shake out come the vote?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We’d run them close. And we’ve gone further than I ever imagined. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But on latest projections, at our best pace... We’d come up anywhere between three to five votes short.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How accurate is your vote count?

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: Very. Despite the dour circumstances, Esme regards Ross with a Always the sloucher, he straightens.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (beat; considers) Alright, that’s all. There’s nothing more we can do tonight. The team lethargically get up, suddenly reluctant to aban their post.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, I don’t need to leave. Could rally the troops on the West Coast and-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Get some rest, Franklin. You’ve done enough for today.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (channeling Elizabeth) Not if we’re going to be three to five votes down.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'll take to the streets right now and rip down those fucking Frank McGill posters one at a time if I have to.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That's a logistical nightmare I'd happily partake in.

dialogues.speaker: ESME
dialogues.text: ++. Our colors are still nailed to the mast, Elizabeth. Elizabeth looks at the intrepid faces of her small, loyal team. Her exterior barely registers it, but she's genuine touched and impressed.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The war will still be here tomorrow, guys. Go home and sharpen your knives. See you all first thing. After a beat, they relent and take their exits. Elizabeth remains in her seat. Rodolfo gives her a moment as she af her stare on her young colleagues as they file out.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: What now?  94.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We fight the good fight, and hope for the best.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You coming? She shakes her head and Rodolfo exits. Elizabeth hesitate Decisively, she pulls out her cell, and makes a call.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S., FILTERED)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, you have the wrong number.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Silly me. I should have written it down. She hangs up, and puts her phone away. Savors the silence a moment. She gropes in her handbag for the TRINKET BOX. it open to reveal two little white pills. Elizabeth stare them contemptuously. Wants them, but knows she shouldn't. Jaw clenched in frustration, Elizabeth gets up and stomps to a trash can, heels stabbing the floor with every strid Her hand hovers over the receptacle, but wavers - she can let go. Until -- she drops the trinket box in the trash, turns away quickly. Paces. Hands fidget, eyes dart around room. Frustration builds, and Elizabeth lets out a FERAL SCREAM KICKS the trash can over - papers scatter across the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near breaking-point, she gathers herself. Calms her breat The trinket box sits on the floor, glistening under tube lights. Taunting her. She walks over and picks it up, a disappointment in her eyes for a battle lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks toward her car, finally finished for the evening. She sees Clara and Alex in conversation near her black Mercedes S-Class, and initially thinks nothing of i removes the key fob from her pocket. A little closer in, she stops. Observes them from a dista They’re talking, smiling, as though both know they should their separate ways, but neither wants to part. Like awkw college kids on a first date. Elizabeth smiles faintly, a touch ruefully. She hangs bac not wanting to interrupt. She looks elsewhere for a moment, but can’t help but look to see Clara give Alex a quick kiss and smile before spli off to their cars. Elizabeth unlocks her car and gets in.  95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth closes the door and silence envelops the luxury cabin. She hits the start button and the engine PURRS. Th player resumes some vaguely upbeat classical music - Rachmaninov’s Italian Polka. No more than two seconds pass before Elizabeth shoots an out to shut it up. She sits for a moment’s silence, seale in her little bubble. Finally, she belts up and pulls out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane presents stats to Bob Sandford and the Gun Lobby tea

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The public is overwhelmingly in favor of gun control. They’ve exploited this and secured the finance necessary to mount a serious challenge.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Is there not some saturation point? Where everyone who’s backed their position will have coughed in?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, but with 80% of the American public on their side, there’s still some way to go. With McGill in the news, this is as good as it gets for us.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are your projections?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: If we take all the uncommitted Congressmen and split them 50-50, they win. 60-40, they still win. We’d need 64% to scrape it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: Good God.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How accurate is your count?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: Buy them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They’re already on the payroll.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: Buy them again!

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: Voter pressure’s too strong.  96.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: (to George Dupont) You said you would take care of this. The whole reason I came to this firm was for the woman who’s putting you all to shame-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bob. This bill will not pass.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: How exactly do you plan to stop it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (beat) Clear the room please. Those who know to exit take their leave. George, Bob Sand Connors, and R.M. Dutton remain.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The only reason we’re here is because of one person. Without her, we walk all over them.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: What are you suggesting?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We need a way to remove her from the Heaton-Harris campaign, put her on the defensive. For example, a Congressional hearing into her unorthodox lobbying practices.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: How would such a thing come about?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I know of a Congressman who may be open to the idea. But it would take a lot of persuasion.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDFORD
dialogues.text: I‘1l put up whatever it takes to kill that amendment.

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: Hold on. You’1l need a convincing allegation of impropriety as the basis for an investigation.

dialogues.speaker: CONNORS
dialogues.text: I'd give my left nut to drag her rep through the dirt, but you’re not gonna get it. She’s a CYA specialist, I never met anyone so pedantic in my life.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The least we can do is look for it. (gets up) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want everyone in this whole damn firm interviewed - no - I want anyone who ever shared a room with her interviewed. We'll see how well covered her ass really is.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: She wouldn’t let us cut corners. A large part of my job involved researching the legality of our strategy, if there was any exposure she'd hold off.

dialogues.speaker: R.M. DUTTON
dialogues.text: Any questionable surveillance, tapping, anything of that nature?

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: Everybody knows she did it, but we never dealt with those guys. She kept them separate. For evidence purposes, they don’t exist.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: She'd ply Congressmen with benefits. Free meals, tickets to events, golfing weekends. All paid for by our clients, via the firm.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, that right there’s enough-

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. She’d make a point of invoicing them. Every single benefit, from a flight ticket to a glass of champagne, she made me keep receipts and invoice the Congressmen. Sure, there was an understanding they’d never pay, but we’d always send an invoice. The debt shows as an asset on our balance sheet, we can theoretically call it in any time we want.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And that’s legal?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Apparently so. You know, now that you ask, there was a time... (hesitates) Ah, it’s nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Tell me about it.  98.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Just a silly technicality, I didn’t even notice, it was Franklin-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jane. I know she mentored you, and you have a lot of respect for her, but you chose this firm. If you have any inkling of misconduct...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What would happen? To her?

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: (lying) , Nothing! We’re mining for leverage, get her to stay out of Nebraska.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (beat) There may have been a financial irregularity she glossed over. With the Kenyans, palm oil, the Nutella tax. I think she might have violated the gift ban.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Dupont approaches a parked Lexus. He gets into the passenger side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Dupont closes the door and takes a brief repose, EXHALES. In the driver's seat sits the man leading the ch in our congressional hearing: Ron M. Sperling. In private paternal, sanctimonious demeanor gives way to a curtness expected of a seasoned political schemer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Things not looking so good for the mid-terms, Ron. You ask me, you're gonna need a lot more TV time.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: I didn’t ask you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Now, who might just be able to fund those coveted TV spots?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: I’m committed to Heaton-Harris, I can’t vote for it with one hand and choke it with the other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It needn't look that way. You’1ll be leading an inquiry into Sloane’s affairs in response to an article exposing her litany of misdeeds.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: What article?  99.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We're arranging it.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: The cost of hearings run into the millions. That’s public money-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ron, the Gun Lobby have identified you as the man to pull this off. If you decline, I can’t stop them blitzing you with negative finance, which, sure as your shit doesn’t smell like root beer, they will. They won’t stop until they annihilate you. D’you know the root meaning of the word ‘annihilate’? It’s Latin. It means, reduce to nothing. That’s what they’re going to do to you, Ron.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: So what, I'll be taking a wedge from the Lobby and leading the attack on Heaton-Harris’ biggest proponent? A sixth-grader could connect the dots.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We can create a structure to obfuscate the source. Your big wedge will arrive courtesy of eight to twelve smaller entities with no affiliation to guns.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: How big a wedge are we talking?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Big enough to be the difference between the continuation of your duties as a member of Congress, and the reduction of your career to nothing. The article’s coming. George exits the car, leaving Sperling to consider his wo Suddenly agitated, Sperling BRUSHES vigorously at his for which rests on the center console, as if swatting at some persistent itch. INT. PETERSON WYATT - RODOLFO’S OFFICE - DAY - PAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodolfo Schmidt and Elizabeth’s secretary LORRAINE sit at table. Elizabeth takes her seat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This had better be good. I’ve got viral video to produce.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I was sorting your letters, and between the hate mail and death threats, I found this. Lorraine hands Elizabeth a letter.  100.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pru West of The Star is running a feature on the lobbying industry. Actually, on you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (reading; then: ) And she wants to meet me, why the hell did she send a letter?

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Because she doesn’t really want to meet you. She wants to say she reached out to you for an interview and never heard back. (off Elizabeth’s look) An insider at The Star got in contact. Word is, it’s a hit.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well, the least I can do is disappoint her. (to Lorraine) Set it up.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You're not leaving this damn building without an attorney. Our in-house guy’s perfect. I don’t believe you two have met. INT. PETERSON WYATT - POSNER’S OFFICE - DAY - PAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodolfo Schmidt and one Daniel Posner are mid-argument.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You know how I feel about this, I was against you ever hiring her-

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Because your job isn’t winning lobbying fights, it’s keeping us from getting sued-

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: And the woman’s a liability, quite independently of her being utterly contemptible-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits and waits outside. She can see them in sil heated discussion behind the glass. Rodolfo opens the doo

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Liz, meet your protection.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Daniel Posner, Head of Legal.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Liz Sloane, contemptible liability. And amateur lip-reader! Whose idea were the glass walls, seriously?  101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth shakes hands with PRU WEST, who introduces GORD

dialogues.speaker: PRU WEST
dialogues.text: So kind of you to meet at short notice. This is Mike Gordon from our legal department.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Daniel Posner from ours. Pru West and Elizabeth sit. Gordon and Posner follow. Gor sets a dictaphone down on the table. Posner does likewise There’s a very obvious hostility behind all the niceties.

dialogues.speaker: PRU WEST
dialogues.text: Ms. Sloane. You’re at the forefront of an industry with a very bad rep. D’you think it’s deserved?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes. When a company forks out campaign contributions to a Congressman who then supports legislation favorable to that company, the public see bribery. Because that’s what it is.

dialogues.speaker: PRU WEST
dialogues.text: Can the system change?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Even if you take the money out of it, lobbying will never go away. At its core, lobbying is about relationships. You can’t outlaw relationships.

dialogues.speaker: PRU WEST
dialogues.text: But the bribery you described earlier, that can change?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes, but it won’t. The two parties capable of effecting change have no interest in doing so. Why would Congress change a system they profit from?

dialogues.speaker: PRU WEST
dialogues.text: Who’s the second party?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You are. The media. It’s far easier to generate hatred for individuals than it is for abstract systems, so you don’t go for the system, you go for the personality. You choose scandal over insight, and who can blame you, readers respond to it. If you don’t feed it to them, your rival will, you’ll go bust and lose your job. Which brings me to my question for you: why are you wasting my time?  102.

dialogues.speaker: PRU WEST
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're asking me abstract questions about the nature of lobbying which, sure as you were born crying, will not form the basis of your article. I’m going to go out on a limb and say this meeting is nothing more than an exercise in box-ticking, and your article's already written.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: (to Pru West) Don’t respond to that. (to Elizabeth) That’s purely speculative on your part, if you have any evidence of this, by all means produce it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Like I said, I’m going out on a limb. Pru West smiles smugly, knowing Elizabeth is right but powerless to stop the process. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Who is controlling you?

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Let’s not do this.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why now?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: The fact is, you have no way of knowing what Ms. West intends to do with the information gleaned from-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s clear you have no interest in what I have to say-

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: And how would you know that?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (beat) Your dictaphone’s off. Elizabeth exits. Posner grabs his dictaphone and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire room engrossed in the D.C. Star.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It’s a hit alright.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I thought it could’ve been worse.  103.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I got four factual errors so far.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: This isn’t good.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Stop fussing. Put The Star in the recycling. They’1l make pencils out of it, maybe one will find its way into the hand of a reporter with some integrity. It’ll go away. INT. PETERSON WYATT - RODOLFO’S OFFICE - DAY - PAST WHACK! A week has passed, and Ross dumps two large lever files, both bursting at the seams, on Rodolfo’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Every attack since the Pru West hack- job that kicked it all off. Every single one just the right side of libelous.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: So much for it going away.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: My personal favorite is the one about how you toppled the High School Head Prefect in a fabricated plagiarism scandal. I’m assuming that’s not libelous ‘cause I can totally see it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: God, that witch was insufferable.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: This is serious. That Sperling’s got the hots for you, do you two have a past?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I barely know him, it’s a put-up.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: This could result in an indictment.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I‘ll have to resign anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, for what?! Why?!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (points to folders) That. Heaton-Harris gets colder with every day I remain associated with it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We're 29 days ‘til the vote, still five votes down and losing ground. If they're orchestrating this, that’s exactly what they want-  104.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And our only play is to give it to them.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: She's right.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We can’t run the campaign without-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nonsense, of course you can. I need to lawyer up for an indictment.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You didn't do anything.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No, but we did. We got too close. INT. PETERSON WYATT - POSNER’S OFFICE - DAY - PAST Posner reclines in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Dan Steinitz. Len Watts. Edmund Gross. High-profile Federal indictment, that’s who you hire.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I want you.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Great! My first action as your attorney is to advise you to fire me, and hire one Dan Steinitz, Len Watts, or Edmund Gross.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We may have our differences-

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You didn’t just wander into the offices of Hackney Carriage, alright? If I wanted to work for people like you, I’d have taken the offer from Cole Kravitz Waterman.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So we can’t agree on the color of the sky, I can’t help thinking you've misjudged me.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: I can live with that.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This will be news for months. Career- defining. If you can make room for the possibility you might be wrong about me... Don’t tell me you don’t want a swing at this. Posner folds his arms. He does want a swing at this.  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: September 21, 2015 Posner, Alex, and Elizabeth talk at crossed purposes.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: (to Alex) We’re on in minutes, you need to get out of here-

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Shearman, Ohio, d’you know anything we can hit him with?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not off the top of my head, I’11l look into it first chance I-

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: This isn’t her job any more!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to Posner) You work for the Lobby now? ‘Cause that was their plan all along.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: I. Don’t. Care. My job is keeping her out of jail. You’re done here. Alex exits. Elizabeth calls out:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How's it looking? Alex shakes his head. Not happening. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Find a way, get to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman Sperling questions Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Regarding your representation of the Kenyan government... Senator Len Davies, the sponsor of the bill you dubbed the ‘Nutella Tax’, was flown to Kenya first-class and put up ina five-star hotel, only a week before the bill was dropped. Our audit puts the cost of this trip at over $20,000. Did the Senator ever reimburse these expenses?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Was he ever invoiced for them?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Was there any expectation that Senator Davis would repay this?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The trip was paid for by the Kenyan Government. If you’re implying I violated the gift ban, you’re barking up the wrong tree. Sovereign states are exempt from the gift ban under Chapter 2 of the House and Senate Ethnics Manuals.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: You sure the Kenyans paid for that trip? See, I don’t think they did. (beat ) The trip was funded from a pooled account. Is it not true that one of your staff raised a concern, which you hastily dismissed?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I‘1l1 tell you what I told Franklin Walsh. The Kenyan Government contributed enough to that account to cover the trip five times over.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: But it’s true that the account contained funds from private entities? F&B conglomerates?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Their contributions made up one quarter of the total, yes.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Is it not also true that, because the Kenyans instructed you late on this, funds from private entities were already in the pooled account when the Kenyans transferred their funds in?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes, I believe so. Posner looks crestfallen. He knows what this means. MEDIA ratchets up. They smell blood.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: (beat; nods) Well. We have ourselves a smoking gun. This is a violation of Chapter 2 of the Senate Ethics Manual, which prohibits the furnishing of money or gifts from a private entity to a member of Congress.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I repeat, the trip was furnished by the Kenyan government-—  107.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that’s not accurate. In accordance with Regulation 17, subsection (d) of the Financial Accounting Standards Board guidelines, funds in a pooled account are to be treated under a principle known as FIFO. First In, First Out. It means that money paid into a joint account first, is the first money to be paid out of it when the account is drawn upon. The effect of this, is that the Kenyan Government didn’t contribute one dime towards the $20,000 that was spent on Senator Davis’ trip. It was covered by the sixteen private entities who first contributed to that account. Which puts you, as the one who authorized the transfer, in violation of the Congressional gift ban. Elizabeth freezes for a moment, blind-sided. It doesn’t l

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (incredulous) FIFO? That’s your trump card? You drag me in for a week of hearings, indelicately wedge an endoscope up my posterior, and all this time, the only incriminating item in your possession is an accounting snafu? One wonders why this wasn’t over in two hours flat. It’s almost as though you've held some kind of special interest in dragging this process out as_long as possible.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: I have a duty to be thorough in my investigations. After all, I represent the people of the United States of America. (beat) This concludes my questioning of the witness. Thank you, Ms. Sloane. Elizabeth gets out of the hot seat and takes up a positio next to Posner. As she does, Congressman Sperling announc CONGRESSMAN SPERLING (CONT’D) We have one further witness we’d like to call.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: (whispers, to Elizabeth) FIFO? Seriously?. Maybe you’re not so sleazy after all.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: The people call Mr. Robert Forde. Elizabeth’s face drops upon hearing the name.  108.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t bet on it. Seeing her reaction, Posner knows this is bad and pipes u

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, I don’t recall being given notice of your intention to-

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: We have only recently been able to locate the witness, Mr. Posner.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Posner) Let it play.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, a moment with my client please. They confer. For the first time, Elizabeth seems broken.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: What is this? Who’s Robert Forde?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I don’t know why I’m even surprised. How stupid I’ve been...

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: I can raise an objection, we can-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Let it play, damn it, they’ll get it out there one way or another. A beat. Posner relents. LATER, Forde is escorted to the stand by a Capitol Police officer. He looks at Elizabeth but she won’t meet his gaz

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Mr. Forde, please raise your right hand. Do you solemnly swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, under pains and penalties of perjury? Forde hesitates for a moment. A quiet anger on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Mr. Forde, could you please describe the nature of your work?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I got many jobs. PT, fitness modelin’ on the side...

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: What would you say earns you the bulk of your income at present?  109. Forde clenches his jaw. He leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I work as an escort in D.C. The media BUZZ heightens.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: You... sleep with women for money?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I meet the client’s needs. Sometimes, that’s bein’ on their arm. Sometimes more. You’d be surprised how many women just wanna sit ‘n talk to someone from a different neck’a the woods, who ain’t gonna judge ‘em. Forde glances to Elizabeth, remembering their earlier conversation. She can’t even look at him.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: But... part of your job entails having intercourse for payment?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: ~-. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Have you ever met Elizabeth Sloane?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Could you please identify her? Forde nods to Elizabeth. Her head remains bowed and she continues to avert her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: What was the nature of your relationship? Forde hesitates. The media salivate.

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: I was attendin’ a function with a client. Ms. Sloane was there. I tried to introduce myself, but she bucked me off. Congressman Sperling's face hardens. In the gallery, Geor Dupont shoots R.M. Dutton a piercing glare, who looks jus shocked. Elizabeth now looks at Forde. Not the answer any them was expecting.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Mr. Forde, have you ever entertained Ms. Sloane as a client?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: «+. No.  110. Elizabeth tries her best to hide her surprise, but there’ touch of confusion on her face; Forde’s behavior is not conforming to her expectation nor world view.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Mr. Forde, may I remind you that you are speaking under oath, and any statement which is later proved to be materially inaccurate may expose you to liability for perjury before Congress. This is a serious offense, and carries the suitably serious sanction of incarceration. I ask again, did you entertain Ms. Sloane in any capacity as a client?

dialogues.speaker: FORDE
dialogues.text: «+. No. I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: (hardened) Thank you, Mr. Forde. You’re dismissed. Forde exits the stand and is walked out by Capitol Police Elizabeth watches him go, confused and genuinely touched he put his head on the block to protect her. INT. PETERSON WYATT - POSNER’S OFFICE - NIGHT - PRESENT Elizabeth, Rodolfo Schmidt, and Posner sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: FIFO. You’re supposed to be the most debased, corrupt operative on the hill, and the only thing they can nail you with is FIFO.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: It’s enough to put you behind bars.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I doubt they’1l bother. They got what they wanted.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: They wanted you behind bars.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Ross! Ross appears in the doorway. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) How’s our old friend Heaton-Harris?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Comatose on its death bed. The whole issue’s gone cold.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Posner) That’s what they wanted.  111.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Shameless bastards. That stunt with the prostitute - anyone who knows anything about you will know how utterly preposterous that is. Elizabeth and Posner exchange a quick glance. RODOLFO SCHMIDT (CONT’D) We fought the good fight. Got closer than we had any right to.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You didn’t hire me to get close. (To Ross) What would it take to revive it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Right now, it’s not even making it to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What would it take to revive it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Seriously? An earthquake. Elizabeth nods, as if finally conceding defeat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well. I should get going.

dialogues.speaker: RODOLFO SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: We'll all be there tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (exiting; stops) Hope for an earthquake. INT. ELIZABETH’S HOUSE - NIGHT - PRESENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim lighting in Elizabeth’s living room. Something about has changed since we were last here: a sparse arrangement high-end furniture, coffee tables and tasteful lamps. Most notable is the absence of work-related clutter. No papers, folders, or file boxes. A vibrant potted plant wh there was nothing before. Dare we say, like a home. The Litigators lies face-down on a side table. Next to it the comfortable armchair used for reading, Elizabeth recl in deep, peaceful sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s packed to the rafters and BUZZING. Public gallery fu familiar faces. Connors, George Dupont, R.M. Dutton, Jane Rodolfo Schmidt and the whole of the Peterson Wyatt team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same room where we first met Elizabeth and Posner. Professional to the last, Posner coaches her on proceedin  112.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: They're going to ask you if you want to make a statement before they read your sentence. Don’t make a statement. Got it? No good can come of you making a statement. You’1l expose yourself to contempt of Congress, defamation-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Don't make a statement. Just decline, and move on.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Anything else? Or can we just go in there and get this over with? Posner nods. Elizabeth stands, straightens her jacket: sh too, professional to the last. She turns to leave when --

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Liz? Posner hesitates. Extends his hand to Elizabeth. He would dare admit he was wrong about her, but they both know tha what it means. This time, she shakes. Proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is marched to the dock by CAPITOL POLICE OFFICE The ever-sanctimonious Ron M. Sperling presides.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Ms. Sloane. Before we proceed to the business of sentencing, you are entitled to make a statement, reflecting on your crime. Is there something you'd like to say?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes, Congressman, there is. Posner closes his eyes. Why does he even bother?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Take all the time you need.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: When I received an offer to take up a position advocating for gun control, I was under no illusions of how difficult it would be.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Ms. Sloane, is this a reflection on your crime, or your recent efforts to-  113.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Mr. Sperling, you've effectively spent the last seven days prying into every detail of my personal and professional existence, not to mention the fact you just permitted me to take ‘all the time I need’. So, with all due respect, shut up. A pregnant collective pause permeates the entire room. Sperling studies her, a suppressed smirk beneath his perv professional decorum.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Proceed. Elizabeth hesitates to compose herself, gather her though

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: My work as a lobbyist has been defined by a peculiar kind of conflict. I’ve made a career from defending my clients’ attempts to maximize their profit. I loathe to use words such as ‘duty’ and ‘responsibility’, because I don’t believe such concepts to be bases for human behavior. I’ve advocated strongly for self-interest as the only rational basis. She looks at Posner. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) I recently told my attorney that ideology is dead; that people merely co-opt whichever political school of thought best serves their desire to profit personally. Looking back on my history of representations, I can only marvel at how wrong I was. Backs straighten in the public gallery, surprised at the of contrition. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) My decision to refuse the Gun Lobby, and to work for the Heaton-Harris campaign, was decidedly contrary to the interests of my career, reputation, my bank balance, and sanity. I’ve been branded a master manipulator, and a parasite on American democracy. I must say, I took the job at Peterson Wyatt for reasons which weren’t entirely consistent with my world view. Forde stands at the back of the gallery, listening intent her every word. Elizabeth’s eyes flash to him.  114. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) I guess, sometimes, people challenge themselves - do things they don’t fully understand, that don’t make sense to them, or even things they’re not comfortable with... Not from any self-serving impulse to protect their lot, but as a matter of principle. Because they happen to believe, in the circumstances, it’s plainly and simply the right thing to do. Forde straightens, raises his head, as if he knows she’s talking to him. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Next Sunday, it will have been eight months since Claudia, Lisa, and Hannah Patterson were shot dead, without rhyme or reason, in the Southridge Mall, Greendale, Wisconsin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel Patterson (from page 41), who lost his wife and chil in the shooting, is glued to Elizabeth’s speech on TV, ta it all in, resolute in his efforts to hold back tears.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (beat) I wasn’t personally acquainted with these people, nor have I ever known a gun victim. But there are many out there who aren’t so lucky. Joel Patterson, a loving husband and father. Their friends and teachers, past and present. Anyone whose lives those three innocent people would have touched. They need a voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (CONT’D) The truth is, I took on each and every one of my representations because I believed, as a matter of ideology, in the causes I for which advocated. (echoing George Dupont) Some may regard this as ‘infantile, save-the-world idealism’, but I’ve come to realize that conviction- lobbying served my interests very well; it catapulted me over the legions of mercenaries, to the very top of my industry; all without playing golf, or being a man. CHUCKLES from the crowd. Rodolfo Schmidt smiles widely, e glazed, remembering their very first conversation.  115. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) My point is this, and there’s no better place to make it than on national TV, before America’s assembled press... Brian and Ross share a look, remembering when they bemoan the absence of a platform for their under-publicized caus Their wheels turning: Did Elizabeth orchestrate all of th ELIZABETH (CONT’D) What sets humans apart is our capacity for reason. The foresight to realize that our interests are best served not by short-term grabs for personal gain, but by holding a real ideology... Cherishing it; using it as a guide for all our decisions and our actions. We can maximize our gain not by engaging in zero-sum games of I-win-you-lose, but by cooperating - doing what we believe is right, not just for ourselves, but for everyone. We'd all be better off this way, individually and collectively; we could all have it so much better - with so little effort, if only we could just see-- Elizabeth, usually so controlled and eloquent, stumbles o her words. The wall of granite has crumbled. She looks to colleagues in the gallery, each full of pride and admirat ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Now, I know I’m not the easiest person in the world to work with, but in this room sit two sets of people with very different ideologies. They found common ground and made huge sacrifices in their careers and personal lives, all in the name of doing what they believe is right. One almost lost her life in the process. Esme holds her gaze, her own walls finally coming down. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Some put their identity on the line to serve a cause which ultimately protects the essence of what that very identity means to them. Clara clenches Alex’s hand, a lump in her throat, knowing Elizabeth has finally given her the acknowledgement she’s longed for. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) These people are not disinterested altruists. They’re just smart enough to realize that their own interests are best served by doing the right thing for society as a whole.  116. The team sit, wide-eyed, surprised, and moved by her trib In another section of the public gallery, Jane sits next George Dupont. She shares their expression. Elizabeth casts her gaze toward the six present Congressm who sit on the panel. They contemplate her words. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) I urge members of Congress to do likewise, and exercise their power and influence in a manner that benefits everyone, not just themselves. Many an honest politician has tried, only to be promptly voted out, because there’s always someone - some rat - who’s prepared to stoop lower than the rest to get his nose in the trough, and by so doing, turn the entire electoral process into a race to the bottom. Now she aims a pointed stare at Congressman Sperling hims who sits in stone-faced silence. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) Make no mistake. These are the real parasites on American democracy. Elizabeth tightens up her softening emotions, and levels chin, takes in the room. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) This game is one of trust; it only works when everyone is playing. People say, ad nauseam, that they want change. I appeal to our finest nature - for want of a better expression - to be that change. The packed room is stunned quiet. Journalists regard her earnestly. Photographers have stopped snapping, put their equipment down. Nobody expected this, not even Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: (whispers ) That’s not exactly the meme.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (emotional; under breath) Shut up, Brian.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Right. It’s not important. In the public gallery, Jane turns to George Dupont.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Mr. Dupont. I’d like to discuss my future.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is hardly the time. Back on the stand, Elizabeth sips from a glass of water, composes herself. Partially restores the granite wall.  117.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Lobbying is about foresight. About anticipating your opponent’s moves and devising countermeasures. The winner plots one step ahead of the opposition, and plays her trump card just after they play theirs. It’s about making sure you surprise them, and they don’t surprise you. Posner's eyes narrow. He’s heard this spiel before, right the start of the hearings. ELIZABETH (CONT’D) I anticipated that if I got sufficiently close with Heaton- Harris, there may be an assault against me personally to stall our momentum and tarnish our credibility. Jane turns to Dupont again.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Actually, it is. She hands him an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My resignation. (she stands) Academia’s more my scene. Jane pivots and exits. Dupont regards the envelope like i contains test results for Anthrax poisoning.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Ms. Sloane, I think it’s about time-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Before I left Cole, Kravitz, and Waterman, I retained an operative of mine in their ranks. This sends the media into a FRENZY. Dupont’s eyes WIDEN. looks back after Jane. His ass is on fire.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF FLASHBACKS
dialogues.text: - Ross breaks bad news to the team:

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We'd run them close. And we've gone further than I ever imagined. But on the latest projections... We'd come up anywhere between three to five votes short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Elizabeth alone in the Strategy Room, phone to her ear:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Silly me. I should have written it down. - Jane briefs the Bob Sandford and the Gun Lobby team:  118.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: If we take all the uncommitted Congressmen and split them 50-50, they win. 60-40, they still win. We'd need 64% to scrape it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How accurate is your count?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU on ASPHALT. A cybernetic COCKROACH, wearing an electr backpack scurries along the black top. VIA A TELEPHOTO LENS - George Dupont approaches a parked Lexus.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SAM
dialogues.text: That's it, he’s going for the car. Black Lexus. (mock German) Vo ist Ahnuld? BACK IN THE PARKING LOT, the robo-roach scuttles up besid front right tire. FROM THE CORNER OF THE PARKING LOT, Big Sam, styled as a homeless guy, controls the cockroach with his iPhone. Dupont stops to open the car door -

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now! The cockroach CHARGES out and clings to the heel of Georg shoe, just as he gets into the car. FLASHBACK: IN CAR -—

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Things not looking so good for the mid-terms, Ron. You ask me, you're gonna need a lot more TV time.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: A plot was hatched to use public funds to bankroll a trumped-up hearing at the behest of the Gun Lobby. I had George Dupont under surveillance until he met with a member of Congress who exhibited sufficient moral bankruptcy to adhere to such a plan. That Congressman was Ronald Michael Sperling. The media climb on top of one another to get a shot.  119.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING
dialogues.text: Order! This is not a platform you can use to make malicious, defamato-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Input DNS address 193.184.216.119 into to a browser, download a file named... Earthquake. Everyone in the room bar Elizabeth and Sperling make a ma rush for their phones and laptops. It’s PANDEMONIUM. INSERT VIDEO - Close-up zoom of Sperling and George Dupon through a car windshield, on a night-vision camera. High quality audio is seamlessly synced.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING, (ON VIDEO)
dialogues.text: I’m committed to Heaton-Harris, I can’t vote for it with one hand and choke it with the other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (ON VIDEO)
dialogues.text: It needn't look that way. You’1ll be leading an inquiry into Sloane’s affairs in response to an article exposing her litany of misdeeds.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN SPERLING, (ON VIDEO)
dialogues.text: What article?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (ON VIDEO)
dialogues.text: We're arranging it.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Sperling BRUSHES his forearm vigorously, as if swatting a some persistent itch. The source of the itch: Mr. Cockroa which burrows under the floor mat.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The entire hearing room has descended into a febrile din cross-talk. Congressman Sperling hyperventilates; his act crumbled. Connors eyeballs space, red-faced, jaw clenched 1,000psi. George is more fatalistic; stony gaze zeroed in on Elizab He rips open Jane’s envelope. Together with her resignati letter is an old, crumpled sheet from a NOTEPAD - the sam given to Elizabeth by Rodolfo the night they met. On it, Rodolfo’s handwritten scrawl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A conviction-lobbyist never cheats. She exposes cheaters. Below, Rodolfo’s quote for Elizabeth is written simply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's eyes betray a glimmer of regret. He got played - tactically, creatively, and ethically - and he knows it. admiration, even. A panelist Congressman BANGS his gavel and shouts:  120.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: In light of these allegations, this hearing is adjourned! He BANGS his gavel again as the room continues to pulsate Elizabeth’s eyes meet those of Rodolfo Schmidt. She gives a subtle, knowing shrug. He nods, now wise to her strateg They finally exchange a sincere smile.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: INT. MINIMUM SECURITY WOMENS’ PRISON - DAY - PRESENT Visiting hour. Posner sits opposite Elizabeth. She has ga a little weight, the color has returned to her face.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You look good.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Prison’s not so bad if you don’t have a penis. The guys shank each other, we form self-help groups. There’s a black market economy in lip gloss. (beat) You know, you’re my first visitor? I wasn’t sure I’d see you here. Posner regards the sentiment with a gentle nod.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: I’m curious. FIFO. That was you, throwing them a bone. Without it, they really would've had nothing to incite the hearing?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: See? Not so terrible after all. I was hoping nobody would notice the breach was committed on the day I departed.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: (figuring) And you withheld this part of your strategy from your deposable team members because...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Five years minimum. Posner regards her, realizing the extent to which he has misjudged this woman.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You instigated the whole thing. Brought the roof of the US Capitol crashing down on your head, put yourself - among others - through all of this. For what, a gun bill?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How’s that doing, by the way?  121.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: The Gun Lobby has supplanted Wall Street as America’s most hated. You'd have to talk to Ross for the numbers, but it’s moving again.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Then it worked. I wouldn’t have moved without a plan to win.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: But for what? This was career suicide. No firm’s going near you, not now. You’re too high-profile.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I knew this would be my last hurrah the moment I conceived it.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You're the champion of self-interest, right? I fail to see how self- immolation in furtherance of a gun bill is in your interests. This was disinterested altruism.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (beat) Career suicide might sound bad... but it’s not when you consider the alternative is suicide by career. Any of my eleven doctors would tell you I’ve served my interests very well.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: (gets it) You really think you can slow down?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I took two years to read a hundred pages of The Litigators. I read the remaining three hundred in four days.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: And on the outside?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: At least now, I have a chance to find out. (she stands) Thank you for coming, Daniel. She offers her hand. Posner gets up, but does not shake.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: Actually, we're not quite finished here. We couldn’t do this earlier because of depositions for the Sloane- gate hearings.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Do what earlier? Posner motions to the waiting area of the visitation wing behind a wall of reinforced glass. Elizabeth looks over -  122.

dialogues.speaker: POSNER
dialogues.text: You got some visitors. -- to see her ENTIRE TEAM: Rodolfo Schmidt, head high, full of admiration and respec Jane, smiling, tears welling; Alex and Clara hold hands, now a couple; Ross applauds from afar, his mind still blown by her ruse Esme, dressed casually and looking more relaxed than ever Brian, Lauren, and Franklin complete the equation. They m their way past security. Elizabeth doesn’t know how to react; the idea that they’v taken time out of their busy lives, traveled all this way just to see her, to be there for her - it’s too much. She starts to tear up, and turns away instinctively, loat to show any weakness in public. But this is the one battl knows she can’t win. She turns back and moves toward her colleagues - now, unequivocally, her friends too. Jane is first to greet her, and they enter into a long embrace. Emotions bubble over. The rest of her team gathe round. All look very much at ease. Dare we say, like a fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A familiar sight. A packed house, not a spare seat in the gallery. Cameras SNAP. That pulsating BUZZ of anticipatio

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're live from Capitol Hill where George Dupont and Congressman Ron Sperling are due to face charges of conspiracy, corruption, and abuse of powers. If found guilty, both men could face lengthy jail sentences... MEDIA FRENZY as Congressman Sperling and George Dupont ar marched to their seats by a phalanx of CAPITOL POLICE.
